div.p: THE TOWN-SHIFTS, OR, THE Suburb-Juſtice: A COMEDY.
As it is Acted at His Royal Highneſs the Duke of York's Theatre.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Dring, at the White Lyon next Chancery-Lane, in Fleet-ſtreet: And William Cademan, at the Pope's Head in the Lower Walk of the New-Exchange. 1671.

div.head: TO His Worthy, and Eſteemed good Friend, STEPHEN MOSEDELF, Eſquire.
div.p:
THe favours I have ſo frequently found from your continual kindneſs, is the occaſion I have taken the Confidence to kiſs your hand with this homely Offer of my ſincere Services. I know your Ingenuity will eaſily diſcover thoſe imperfections which your Generoſity will as quickly pardon. But leſt they ſhould come too faſt, and fall too heavy upon your patience, be pleaſed to take this truth as an allay. That it was thought on, begun, and finiſhed, in a fortnight: therefore unlike to appear ſo Correct, as in reaſonable expectation a Play
ſhould be, before it paſſes Stage-proof. I muſt confeſs it a great defect of Judgment in me, and expect to be accuſed of much irrational Confidence, for committing this Minor to make its way through ſo large a Congregation of Criticks, as appear in the perſecution of all Plays. But tis with me, as with Animals, that boldly attempt ſwimming, wanting reaſon to apprehend the water fatal: So I (without fear of Cenſorious Laſhes, which a wiſer Man might have expected to be the Concluſion of ſuch an Adventure) have plung'd my ſelf unawares into a mercileſs Sea of Satyriſts; which I fear will prove Fatal, if I find not protection under your Patronage.
Which is the humble requeſt of,

closer.signed: Your Obliged, and Obedient Servant, EDW. REVET.

lg.l: YOu are of late, Gallants, grown ſo ſevere,
Plays on the Poſt are damn'd, before you hear:
Why ſhould you be ſuch ſtrangers to remorſe,
To Judge, before you try? The faireſt Courſe,
Could we for once adviſe, would be to ſtay
And hear the Cauſe, before you giv't away.
But ſince 'tis ſo, we ſcorn to court a ſmile:
Be cruel as you can, ſcoff, and revile
Till you have ſpent your Spleens; that ſo you may
Want them for to condemn a better Play.
This may deſerve the worſt that you can ſay;
Would the Judicious only Criticks be,
They'd do't, where there's juſt cauſe, and moderately.
But there's an up-ſtart Crew, a Generation
Of little Fopps, Criticks by imitation:
Young Men in Flaxen Wiggs, juſt ſent to Town,
For to be cheated, and to wear a Gown.
Theſe are the little things, perch't in the Pitt,
Making of noiſes, which ſome Fools think wit:
Cry down what is now, or what e're was writ.
Be juſt for once, and grant me this demand;
Let me be doom'd by thoſe that underſtand:
Death Glorious looks, brought by a Noble hand.

div.head: Scena prima.
div.p:
THanks to ill Fortune; I have liv'd long enough, and ſpent money enough, to make me poor in pocket, and rich in Experience; in which expence, both of time and money, I've learn'd there's nothing ſo great a fault, or leſs a Mans Friend, that deſires to live in a full Fortune, than Honeſty. My loſſes at Dice have ſufficiently qualify'd me for an expert cheat in that confounded Calling. My Converſation with thoſe kind things, call'd Women, has very well enabled me to perform the gentile profeſſion of pimping, now, of all Vices, moſt in faſhion; and that bluſhing Fool Modeſty's ſo much my Enemy, that I want the confidence to wheadle a poor Taylor to take my raggs off, and new rigg me. Whilſt I had money, never came a Night, but I was Uſher'd home by half a dozen of the Sons of this ſinful Town, to lay me ſafe in my Lodging, but thoſe went with my Money. Yet, Sot that I am, peſter'd with an old faſhion'd Principle of Honeſty, I muſt needs hate to do as I have been done by, though the Devil offers me an excellent opportunity in Young Leftwell, a Fellow
newly come to a large Eſtate, got by his damn'd Father, by the fall of many a fair Family; who has ſcarce wit enough to be made the ſore-man of a Watch. Now, whether it be not Religion to work upon this Animal; faith I think —
div.stage: Enter to him, Friendly, and Faithful.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, how now, Ned, pining in poverty?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Or contriving a way to create new Clothes?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Or, art waiting here with a watry ſtomack, in expectation of an Apparition of Pork and Turnips? 'Sdeath, Ned, this is the worſt way of dyet the Devil could direct thee.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You're merry, Gentlemen; you're merry. Sure, the Devil you ſpoke of, Friendly, has made you ſo; has he not got up into your Garret at St. Giles's, and bought your ſoul for a ſmall morſel of Money? Why, the Spaniſh three-pence I left with you could never produce this ſpirit. You're grown witty, and wanton; what, are you well lyned in the pocket? Come, let's ſee; piſh, never retreat; what a Raſcal are you, to rally thus!

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If your deſign be to ſearch his pockets, prethee deſiſt; for, to my knowledge, they fell out of his Breeches a Moneth ago; and he could have ſpar'd nothing better, for he has had no employment for them this twelve moneth.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pox of your Trumpeters face; muſt you undertake to talk with your plump countenance? I am a Rogue, if I have not ſeen a Butter-eating Dutchman, that has been drown'd nine dayes, appear like a trim Courtier, in compariſon of thee. Thou art a Fellow that wouldſt give thy Ears (for Money thou haſt none) to kiſs the hand of a Kitchin Wench, in hopes to find fat enough upon her fingers, to allay the fury of thy Stomack.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Leave labouring your little wits, and draw near, for I intend you two to be of my Councel.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ned, Ned, we have alwayes found your Counſel to be nothing but perſwaſions to poverty, what a bleſſed thing it is to live Honeſt, and be lowſie; that it is better to be lazy, and lack every thing, than work in the wayes of wickedneſs for wealth.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
The Rogue by chance has clapt upon a truth. 'Tis e'en ſo, Ned. We have fed ſo long upon your Divinity Lectures, that we have almoſt forgot to eat in earneſt, and have hardly Linnen enough left to harbour a Lowſe. Therefore we'le have no more on't,
dear Monſieur Melancholy; for my part, I'm reſolv'd to turn Hector, quarrel in the ſtreets with Drunkards, and ſo ſteal Hats and Perukes; and begin to believe it a very pious way of living; Ay, and 'tis very taking.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: And I'm reſolv'd to follow thee; either fight, filch, padd, or pimp; and no longer ſuffer under the horrid perſecutions of Poverty.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: So, fate you well, Sir; fare you well.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If I thought you were ſuch wretched Raſcals as you are painfully making appear, you ſhould e'en pine in your poverty, e're participate in my pious, and I hope, profitable deſign; but I know yee better. You hear, Gentlemen, that Young Leftwell is come of Age, though not to Years of diſcretion. Do you believe it a ſin to bubble this abominable Brute out of a part of that ill got, and like to be worſe ſpent, Eſtate?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, Ned, I think none at all; but how to do it, will require ſome time to conſider on't: I could make ſhift to do it with the Dye, but the Rogue has been ſo cautious of that from his Cradle, that he ſwounds at the ſight of them.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Then Drinking will do nothing; for a pint of Ale puts a Padlock upon his Pocket; and you may as well perſwade a Presbyterian Parſon to Charity, as him out of a penny; there's no way, but to unlock his leachery by the ſight of a fine ſoft Wench.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O hang him, he was once in Love with his Uncle's Kitchin-Maid, and, (as he calls it) was croſt in his affection; and ever ſince, the Fool faints at the ſight of a Female.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But good Clothes muſt firſt be thought on; for you know we three are at preſent (as a man may ſay) in a very thread-bare condition; which this Clod-pole hates worſe than an Old Alderman does Hunting. 'Tis certain we ſhall never be receiv'd in this garb. Ned, cannot you get the old confiding man, ſweet Mr. Sowell, to new ſuit us, in order to this deſign, with a large promiſe of ſudden ſatisfaction?

div.stage: Enter Leftwell, and his Man Moſes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: See where the Aſſe comes, ſadled in ſilk. Let's all put on ſobriety, and ſalute him.

sp.speaker: Leftw.
sp.p: Moſes, can you tye a ſhooe in the neweſt faſhion?

sp.speaker: Moſes.
sp.p: Sir, I tyed your Fathers a fore you were born, and (peace be with him) he never diſlik'd it.

sp.speaker: Leftw.
sp.p: Come to, then, but have a care of my Corns, good Meſes. How now, Ned, no new Clothes yet; I would you were finer, that you might be fitter for my Company.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I am ſorry, Sir, that my ill garb commands me from your good Company.

sp.speaker: Leftw.
sp.p: Prethee Ned, what are theſe Tatter-demallions that attend thee? they look like men of the forlorn hope, with half their Clothes taken off by ſmall ſhot. 'Slife, there's one has a hole ſhot through his Hat.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Friends of mine, Sir; that you would honour in acknowledging.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt humble Servant; I ſhould be proud to be better acquainted.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sir, I don't know you, nor deſire to be better acquainted with you, till you get better Clothes on your back. There's you, and your Friend, would ſerve for a couple of Scare-crows, if you could get Credit for carriage into the Countrey. I'le plague that Fellow, when I was poor, he perſecuted me.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Td's Death, Lovewell, I ſhall be conſtrain'd to kick him; I cannot hold.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O, by all means do, and ſtarve for't.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Ned Lovewell, how long have you known theſe Raggamuffins?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, an't pleaſe you, Sir, about a dozen years.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Alwayes in the ſame Clothes, I warrant; for leſs time sould never have taken 'em into ſo many pieces. Do you ever lye with them? Are their Shirts any better than their Suits?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You're too great a Tyrant. They are, I aſſure you, Sir, Gentlemen of a very antient Family.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: If their Family be as old as their Clothes, 'tis Antient indeed. God by'e, Gentlemen; if ever I ſee you again, I ſhall certainly dream of a Dung-hill. Come along, Moſes.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What a damn'd Rogue is this? he has abus'd us beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let him talk on; I find now what will do it. I'le ſtrait to ſerious Sowell, and ſollicite him to help us: Meet me about ſeven a Clock at the Old Houſe.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Heavens bleſs thee with the ſpirit of effectual perſwaſion.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Leticia, Fickle, Betty, in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Couſin Fickle, thou haſt ſome of the ſtrangeſt humours in thee, that ever Maid was mad withal. Thou never lik'ſt a dreſs above half an hour, nor a man more than half a day: Thou art a meer Proteus, and put'ſt thy ſelf into as many ſhapes. Thou haſt been this one day in ſix ſeveral dreſſes; and the laſt week lov'd, and hated, ſeven ſeveral Men. No body that knows thee believes thee any thing elſe but diſtracted. We ſhall have thee, e're long, fall out with Life, and dye for diverſion.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: And thou art (Dear Coz.) as mad the other way; thou hadſt rather wear thy Clothes till they are mouldy, then give thy Maid the trouble of a new tyring. That garb and Gown you now go in, is as well known as the Church, and I believe you think it as durable; for Betty ſayes you never intend to change it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O fye; Madam, never truſt me, if ever I talked of your Ladyſhip at this unmannerly rate.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let her run on, Wench; I'm certain ſhe'le be out of love with this way of talking quickly: I've a mind to ſee if ſhe can continue a quarter of an hour in any one thing.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Then, Couſin, thou art mad of one Man. Thou haſt lov'd a Fellow in foul Linnen (I think he's a Gentleman) but what then? thou haſt lov'd him almoſt half a year, which is a horrible thing to think on. But I am weary of the Garden; I'le go talk of Stateaffairs to my old Uncle. Good b'ye, Coz.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Go thy wayes, Mad-cap: I'le undertake, before my Father can turn about and talk two words, ſhe'le be weary of the firſt, and go to find new Company.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, ſhe wearies me out of my little wits, to pin, and unpin Curles; to add, and diminiſh colour; to new place the Pendants: any, ſometimes at Noon day, to put on Coyfes and Pinners. I would to Heaven ſhe were well marryed, that I might not be peſter'd. But now I talk of Marriage, pray, Madam, when did you hear from Mr. Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Not a great while; Betty, I'm afraid I muſt wear the Willow, I doubt he has left me; what think'ſt thou?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O, Madam, I dare ſwear, he had rather loſe his Eyes. If that Man be not truly a Gentleman, there's no Gentility in being. 'Tis a thouſand pities he's poor: In ſpight of his low garb he will look like himſelf; I'le tell you, Madam, when I have light him down ſtairs, and I dare ſwear he has not had three ſhillings in his pocket, he has put half a Crown into my hand, when I was grieved to take it. 'Twere ſin, to doubt his Love.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Betty, I doubt you'le prove my Rival; could you find in your heart to love him, if I ſhould leave him?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: If I could not, I wiſh I might dye a Maid; which would be much againſt my will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Heark, does not ſome body knock at the Garden Gate? Go ſee who 'tis.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I go, Madam; I vow, I hope from my heart 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I love him well; yet, if I marry him, I'm loſt; and left to languiſh in a life of loathed poverty, for he is poor. And 'tis becauſe he has a generous ſoul, he is ſo. My Father cannot hear of him with patience; for he had rather wed me to a Brute, with Money, than to the beſt of Men, that wants it. That Age ſhould ſo defective be in Reaſon; as to prefer this ſordid Dung-hill Earth before the beſt of Gallantry and worth.
But here he comes, and Betty gone; this Baggage never fails to leave him to all opportunities; but I'le act a Womans part, for once; I'le appear ſtrange, to try him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My dear Leticia!

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Soft; Sir, you have been away ſo long, you have forgot your duty. I pityed you whilſt you knew Civility, and for that reaſon indulg'd you; and thought to have perſwaded my Maid to Marry you, and got my Father to put you into a Farm, in hopes you would in a little time become a perfect Plough-man. Your miſ-behaviour now makes me believe now you have been one. And ſo good b'ye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Dear Madam, let me conjure you. —

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, no conjurations; if you have any thing to ſay, ſpeak ſoberly, and at diſtance: I find, allowing you too near addreſs, begets you confidence.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Will not this poſture ſerve, as well as any?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I, truly, I think that beſt becomes you; now go on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Then I proceed, and beg a knowledge of my Crimes; and why I find thoſe killing frowns; a Cloud on that fair face, which
was alwayes wont to wear ſuch ſmiles as ſweetned all my ſorrows, and made me triumph in deſpight of tears. Have I done ill? tell me, that I may dye: 'Twere Villany, to live after a Crime committed againſt you.

div.stage: Enter to them, Pett, her Father.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: How's this? Certainly, that Fellow believes my Daughter to be the Goddeſs Ceres, and he's begging bread. I'faith, I ſhall put you beſides your Petition. De'you hear, Sir; there's nothing for you, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: We're both undone — My Father — what will you do?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Friend, what's your buſineſs here? A man would gueſs by your Clothes you ſhould have more kindneſs for your ſtockings, than to beg on your knees. 'Tis ten to one, whether ſhe had given you enough to have mended what you wore out in your worſhip. But heark you, Sir; I believe, by your face, you come to ſollicite her Love. Pray pack off, Sir, or I'le make my Cane walk about your Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, will you —

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Pray, Sir. Pray me no prays; but be gone, or I ſhall remove you at a very unmannerly rate: Will you ſtir, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me intreat —

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I'le ſpoil your entreaties, with a pox to you. Put this Fellow out of doors, and ſee him pumpt.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Good Sir, have a little pity of the poor Gentleman; being hard purſu'd by Bayliffs, he, to avoyd them, got over the Garden Wall; and fearful he had frighted me, when you came in, was earneſtly asking pardon. Now, Sir, you know the full of his offence, I hope you will retract your Sentence.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I thought 'twas ſome ſuch Run-away-Raſcal; no, he ſhan't be pumpt, but turn him out to the liberty of the Law; let him pay, or to Priſon, a Gods name; turn him out of doors there.

Come, Daughter, I hope in a ſhort time to have a Husband for you; in the mean while I ſhall keep you from ſuch Cattle as this; for I begin to find this is but an excuſe, to hide this beggarly Fellow's kindneſs. Let me ever ſee you with him again, and you ſhall ee'ne to him for altogether, with as many tatters as he has; for I am reſolv'd to diſ-own you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, you know my affections hitherto have waited on your will, and ſhall do ſtill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I wiſh they may; come in with me.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Gentlemen; I ſuppoſe you think I can feed upon Faggot ſticks, or pay my Rent with Cheeſe parings; why, what do you mean, Gentlemen? What do you mean? Muſt I never have my Money? here is now ſeven ſhillings, for ſeven weeks lodging, and as much for dyet, and waſhing the little linnen you have, God knows; this is money in a poor Womans pocket, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Dear Land-lady, be mollified; let not your paſſion put you beſides your Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Talk not to me of Reaſon, wretch, as thou art; give me my Money, I'le make more than one know on't, elſe. Then there's that blundering Sot, your Companion, that ſtands ſneering, and ſays nothing, could come and borrow Money of my Maid; I'le call her, to witneſs it.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, what then, Beldame?

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Well, 'tis very well; if Young Wenches muſt work to lend you their wages.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: You, Dame damnable, hold your bawling tongue, in the Devils name, and ceaſe dunning, or I'le draw it out of your Mouth as long as my Arm.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee hold thy idle prating; you muſt give better words, fore George we ſhall get no Dinner elſe to day. Come, Land-lady, let me perſwade you into peace; a little time will enable us to pay you all: I have a Bill of Exchange to receive a hundred pounds within ſix weeks, and it ſhall all wait upon thy Command, dear Landlady.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you know, Gentlemen, I am as unwilling to ſpeak, as the Child unborn; but when I am forc'd to it, you muſt not take it ill. I want four ſhillings of my Quarters Rent for my Houſe, to make it up five and twenty; if you could but furniſh me with that, it would do me a mighty kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pox of your old, ugly, abominable — no more dunning.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: O you Rogue, I will ask for my own, when you are hang'd. Sirrah, han't I been fain to lend you my own Shift to wear, whilſt yours was waſht, to keep you from being lowſie? Don't you now weat my poor dead Husband's? I cannot ſpeak of him, without tears.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Poor Land-lady, lament no more; 'tis true, Will was an honeſt fellow, and one that liv'd in the fear, as a Man may ſay, and would drink off his quart, or two, of Ale, as quietly as a Quaker, upon another Mans coſt.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I, Mr. Friendly, you knew him. Don't you remember, when I ſold Fruit firſt, how he beat Chriſtopher Crab, the Coſter-monger, for calling o'me Grundy; he would not let a Lamb wrong me: he us'd alwayes to call me his Monkey.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, marry did he. But, Land-lady, I hear you have a Flitch of Bacon ſent you from Will's Friends.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: That I have indeed, Mr. Friendly; and 'tis as good as ever was cut with Knife: And if you will pleaſe to come home at dinner time, and eat a piece, with an Egg, you ſhall be very welcome. It may be done homely, but I'le warrant you cleanly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By this light, Land-lady, I don't know a better Cook then thou art, in all Chriſtendom; and here's honeſt Tom has ſaid ſo a thouſand times.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: 'Tis more your goodneſs, than my deſert, to ſay ſo, Sir. I hope, Mr. Faithfull, you'le take no notice of what I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No notice in the World, Woman; get Dinner ready, wee'le come in time.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Leticia, Betty, at a diſtance.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
My Servant, I'me afraid, is ſomething ſolitary, where e're he is; he cannot chuſe but wonder what's his, fault; my Fathers coming in diſturb'd both him and me: but here I have a Letter ready writ ſhall ſatisfie how well I love him; and that my laſt anger onely was to trye him. How ſad a thing is Love, when it wants liberty? The Man I love is one that does deſerve as much as Man may do; but yet my Father ſays, he that wants Money, conſequently wants Merit. What ſhall I do in this extremity? Love anſwers thus; In having
him, I live; in miſſing him, I dye; I muſt do Cupid Juſtice. — Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I've work for you to do; and ſuch as you'le take kindly: can you find in your heart to carry this Letter to Mr. Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, not contentedly, if I thought it were not kind. Pray, Madam, Commiſerate the poor Gentleman: you have enough for your ſelf, and him, and twenty to attend you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I, but my Father loves him not ſo well as thou doſt. He'le not hear of him that has nothing anſwerable to my full fortune.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: May your Father go into another World then, and let him live no longer, to hinder the happineſs of two ſuch real Lovers.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Away, you Baggage, carry your Letter, and take this purſe; deſire him to pay it where I order'd him; then bring me word, how he takes the Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am gone, Madam.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Thou active god of Love, preſcribe a way To make me happy in a Marriage day.

div.head: Scena quinta.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prethee ſtand farther off, thy breath ſtinks of Red-Herrings, enough to ſtifle a man. I'm ready to run mad; never was man ſo miſerable.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, man? Art clapt by ſome kind Companion? or does thy Conſcience accuſe thee of living too long honeſt?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Or, has Sewell given a ſad denial; ſo that there's no hopes of new Habit?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Gentlemen, though nothing you gueſs at is the cauſe of my diſconte •• ; yet I can tell you that will trouble you; there's little hopes of your being tyred in new Trappings: you may live ſtill in your leather Linings, and increaſe in Cattel. Sewell proves inexorable, as to you, though kind to me. Gentlemen, mine are making; 'tis very true, Gentlemen, I wiſh the caſe were your own; yet I have ſomething ſtill ſticks worſe upon my ſtomack. Prethee ſtand further off, thou'lt ſtifle me with thy breath.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Out upon you, for a fretful fopp; you have been trading
with ſome three-half-penny Wench, that's ſweetned with a pennyworth of Pomatum, and now your Noſe allows nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prethee, Friendly, wilt thou tell me one thing?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, I will.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But will you ſeriouſly?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By this light, I will.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Did you drink to day after your Dinner?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: The Devil's in this Satyrical Fellow; he pretends to be alwayes melancholy, and then he's moſt maliciouſly abuſive.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Our bus'neſs is like to be well carryed on between a couple of conceited Coxcombe. If you can live with laughting at one another, I would have you do nothing elſe; if otherwiſe, why don't we come to the buſineſs? Haſt thou perſwaded the Taylor to provide us Tackle?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, I'le put you out of your pain. What de'e think he ſays?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: De'e call this putting people out of their pain, to ſet their brains upon the Rack to reade your dealings with a damn'd Taylor, that no body knows where to find beſides your ſelf. Prethee, be ſerious but one minute, and let's be ſatisfi'd

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why then I'le tell you. After I had taken a great deal of pains to find him, and inquired at every Houſe where they ſold a ſeal'd quart for two pence.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, then I miſt him. And I aſſure you, never ſaw him ſince I ſaw you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, you have taken a great deal of pains, and made a mighty buſtle, to bring forth nothing.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I'le be hang'd if he has not been drunk ever ſince in a Chimney corner, with ſome Weavers Wife, without More-Gate; and at laſt been beaten out by her Husband, and that makes him melancholy.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Servant, Mr. Lovewell; will you give me leave to ſpeak one word in private with you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Pretty Mrs. Betty; I'le wait on you inſtantly. Pray, dear
Friends, leave me now. At Night I'le meet you, and give you (I hope) a good account of all our concerns.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ned, Ned, this won't do; this is a little unkind: you have had a ſhare in a Miſtreſs of mine, e're now. What need you make theſe pretences to put us off? We know your meaning, never mince the matter, man; ſhe is a very pretty Wench; I would I were with her where thou haſt been.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I faith, Franck, ſhe's very civil. Let me deſire you to lay aſide all thoughts to the contrary, and you ſhall command me any thing. Prethee leave me a little.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Don't believe him, Franck; he'l feign a hundred things to fobb us off: but if I ſtir without a ſhare in this prize, I'le be pegg'd to a poſt for boys to throw rotten Pears at. Remember, Ned, you would not leave me one Morning, when my Landreſs came to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, I ſee you're engag'd. I'm ſorry I came at this unlucky time to trouble you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Dear Mrs. Betty, I beg your pardon; I am but giving theſe two Bayliffs directions about a buſineſs that concerns me▪ I ſhall have done in a minute.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I have no more heart to go, than a Man has to play at Dice the day before he's to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me conjure you by all our Friendſhip, not to offer me this moſt unmannerly affront. You don't know what injury you do me. Dear Friends deſiſt, ſhe's one that waits upon a perſon of Quality, and a near relation of mine, and not of that ſtrain you take her; faith, ſhe e'ant.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What a pox, ne're tell us this. I ha' known you my ſelf theſe dozen years, and never ſee any thing with you look like an honeſt Woman; nor will believe this ſo, though thou ſwear it by the ſoul of thy dead Father. What an idle thing is this in you, to perſwade people to things ſo improbable, that know the World as well as you do; To go tell us that a Wench, in this garb, would be ſent to a Gentlemans Chamber at this time o'th day, if there want a deſign to do—Fye, fye.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What harm will it do you, Ned, to let us have a little liberty with this pretty piece of Woman's fleſh? She'le be as fit for you again to morrow, as e're ſhe was. You know we are both ſound.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir; I'le call ſome other time.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Mrs. Betty, I've but a little more to ſay now, and they'le
be fully inform'd in my affairs. Gentlemen, either leave me, or reſolve to fight me; for I would not endure to be thus affronted by my Father. Have you forgot all Friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, hang ye, I love you a little too well yet, to fight with you for a Whore; and ſo good buy to ye.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: 'Tis very fine, that we have liv'd thus long, and muſt now be Hector'd out of a Wench: I ſhall be quit with you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servant; pray be careful in the bus'neſs.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We ſhall take care to requite you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Was ever man thus peſter'd by a couple of Puppys▪ Aſide. Now, Mrs. Betty, I'm ſorry I have been conſtrain'd by the tyranny of bus'neſs, to make you ſtay thus long.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: If it were much longer, Sir, I ſhould not have believed it a trouble, ſince 'tis to ſerve you. For I think I have a Letter here comes laden with Love: if I thought it had not, ſome body elſe ſhould have been the Meſſenger for me; for I hate to be concern'd in any thing that may diminiſh the content of a Gentleman. This is the Letter; and this Money my Lady deſires you to pay where ſhe has appointed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Mrs. Betty, I acknowledge my ſelf much bound to you.

p.hi: I Am ſorry my Father fell ſo unhappily upon us, that hinder'd my Concluſion, which I intended as kind as I began cruel; but however I appear'd then, I am now as you have alwayes found me, that unhappy, but affectionately, Yours,

closer.signed: L. P. As you love me, receive what I have ſent you.

div.p: Moſt bleſſed tydings. Mrs. Betty, pray be pleas'd to pay my humble ſervice to your Lady; and let her know, I chearfully obey her Commands.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, ſhe has laid no more upon you then you are able to bear. Your obedient Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Your humble Servant, Mrs. Betty.
Exit Betty. This comes kindly, and cuts off much of my care; for I find my Miſtreſs faithful, and here's Money to new-Clothe me, and my two Friends.

div.p: How now, Runwell; how doſt thou hold out? canſt thou not find in thy heart to eat?

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: Sir, I believe I ſhould not run away from a piece of a Roaſted Horſe: but let hunger be hang'd, I defie it; feed, or faſt, I'le never leave you, while I live, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Here's Money for you; when you have dyn'd, ſtep to Sewell, the Taylor; bid him come to me.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: By this hand, Sir, if he refuſe to come, I'le bring him on my back.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
Now will I ſet Sewell to work for me and my ill-clad Companions, who I am ſure have gratitude enough to take it kindly.
Then, my young Squire, I'le try what may be done:
Where no game's plaid, there's nothing can be won.

div.head: Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: BY my troth, Girles, you ſpoyl your ſelves with lying ſo long a bed; it makes you look like a great-belly'd Woman that has loſt her longing. Betty, I think I muſt give you a Commiſſion to bang 'em up.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I Vow, Sir, I think you muſt get ſome body elſe to beat me up too then; for the Young Ladies have ſpoyl't me, and made me ready to lye as long as they.

sp.speaker: Fickle.
sp.p: Uncle, your Man has the worſt way of dreſſing you in the World; Sir, he alwayes puts your Ruff on one way. 'Tis an errant ſhame to ſee a Man ſo long in one faſhion, as you have been.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What, art thou mad, Coz? There is but one way of putting on a Ruff, unleſs you would have me wear the fore-part behind.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Look here, Sir, is your Ruff ty'd as my Whisk is? Pray, Sir, let me tye it. I proteſt I'le lay twenty ſhillings I tye it better than Old Ralph has done.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I like it very well, good Couſin, if thou could'ſt like it to let it alone; no body has found fault with it this twenty years, beſides thee. But I know thou wilt never let me alone till thou haſt done it; therefore, prethee diſpatch me quickly.

div.stage: She pulls off one of her Ribbons, and tyes it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Did he receive it with ſuch joy?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Joy! He could have ſaid or done no more, had I come for to ſecure him of eternal happineſs hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I'le be judg'd by all the World now, if it be'nt handſomer by a hundred times; it looks like any Cravat. I vow, Uncle, if my Aunt were alive again, ſhe would a new fall in love with you.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Why, what haſt thou done, Couſin; tyed up my Ruff like a ſhatter'd-brain'd Boy with a Taſſel at my Chin? Prethee give me my Point again. A pox of your Cravats, you ſhall never dreſs me more, I'le aſſure you; here, Leticia, take it you, and tye my Ruff, and let her have her Ribbon.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Well, ſay what you will; I'm certain the Ribbon becomes you better than the Point. Betty, how thy Hood ſits to day! I dare be whipt if thou didſt not dreſs thee without the Glaſs; and this Whish ſits all awry: ſtep up to my Cabinet, I'le lend you one of my lac'd ones.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I thank you, Madam; I had as liff wear this to day.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Well, do then. Uncle, pray when comes my Couſin Lett's Servant? I long to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: You'le be dreſſing of him as ſoon as e're he comes within the doors, I dare ſwear. But to ſatisfie you, the man that loves her, and whom ſhe muſt love (if ſhe loves me) I expect to be here this Morning.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, is he Young, or Old?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Why, Young, very Young; newly come of Age.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Is he a handſom man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Very handſom, I proteſt, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Has he money enough?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I, my good Girle; he has more money than twenty of the Whip-Jacks of this Town, who walk about with a half-ſtarv'd footboy, that has faſted three dayes, and never eats, but when his Maſter treats a Wench.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I, indeed, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: She'le weary my Father out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Is he good-natur'd, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I, truly; I believe the Man to be of a good principle, and will be kind to a Wife.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Did he ever learn to Dance, Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I'le anſwer thee no longer; thou begin'ſt to be very impettinent, Coz.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Will you walk in the Gallery then, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Any where, ſo thou wilt promiſe me not to weary me with thy eternal rattle.

div.head: Scena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Lovewell, Friendly, Faithfull, in their Gallantry.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come, Gallants, move with Majeſty. And ſhew your ſelves to the moſt advantage that may be. Faithfull, you are always looking upon your ſhooe-ſtrings, like a Prentice upon an Eaſter Holy-day. Hold up your Head, and look handſomly; take your Gloves out of your pockets, and put them on your Hands. I'm afraid, if I ſhould take this Rogue into Company, I ſhould be troubled to teach him the way to take off his Hat.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Then the Raſcals Peruke never ſtands the right way; and he makes leggs ſo like a Logger-head, that it would be ſuppos'd we took him out of a Mill, where he had learnt to dance of a Malt-horſe; for there's not a ſtep that he takes in his new ſhooes, but up comes a ſtone in the pavement.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'le undertake, ſhould he go into a Noble-mans Hall, he would ſtamp a row of black and white marble to pieces in leſs than half a minute: never Horſe had ſuch hoofs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And then he's ſo great a Sloven, that by that time he has worn theſe Clothes but three dayes, they'le be lac'd with all manner of liquour, and as greaſie as his old ones are, that the Rats have, ſince he left them off, run away with.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Talk on, Gentlemen, talk on; Cloath me thus but once a
Moneth, and I'le for ever allow you the ſame priviledge you now take of prating. Forgive me, dear Patron, for I cannot chooſe but laugh at you, and that idle fellow, as a couple of very impertinent fopps.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Ned Lovewell, how doſt do, Boy? now I like thee; now thou look'ſt like thy ſelf. Faith, I was reſolv'd to find thee out, and to new-furniſh thee at my own charge; thou wilt not believe how ſad I have been e're ſince I ſaw thee laſt. Let me look round about thee; faith, 'tis mighty rich: prethee what did it ſtand thee in? If I can ſerve thee in any thing, as far as my ſmall Eſtate goes, 'tis all at thy Service, ſweet Rogue.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And I'le try you, Sir, ſince you're in ſo good a humour. Aſide. Sir, I aſſure you you'd do me an exraordinary kindneſs, if you could furniſh me and my two Friends with a hundred pounds, for two or three dayes, no longer.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Pox on him, I thought he would not have faſten'd; would my words were in again.
Faith, Ned, if it will do thee a kindneſs, I cannot tell how to deny it. Here 'tis, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Upon my Honour I'le ſee it ſafe return'd, and eſteem it a very great favour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, you have done us a very conſiderable kindneſs; and in requital, command me any thing.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sir, if you — 'Slife, I ſhall be undone; I was going to offer him as much more, who would, certainly, have accepted it as the firſt.
Sir, I rejoyce I had it to ſerve you.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Sir, I hope we ſhall live to be gratefull, and find a way to make you ſatisfaction for this more than ordinary favour.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sir, there needs none of this. But let me tell you one thing, without offence.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: No exception, I aſſure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Then, faith, I think you become your fine Clothes the worſt of any man that ever wore ſuch.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I muſt confeſs, Sir, I want the way of wearing Clothes well. I can afford to let you prate now, but I'le make your purſe pay for't.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Ned Lovewell, will you aſſiſt me in a deſign? Faith, I am going about to commit Matrimony. Will you help to make Love to my Miſtreſs? I'le aſſure you ſhe's the handſomeſt Woman within a hundred Mile of her; and a Man that has the way of giving good words may win her heart, as I am inform'd, for I never ſaw her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How do you know ſhe's ſo handſom, then?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Why, her Father ſayes ſo, and ſweats he'le ſwinge her, if ſhe refuſe to fall in Love with me, or likes any body elſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What need you have any help, then? Your buſineſs is done to your hand.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: That's true, Mr. Friendly; but I would fain have it done by fair means; and there's Ned Lovewell knows how to work upon a Woman at will. I would fain have him and you go to make up the Match. For his part, he'le be company for nothing but the Horſes; we won't have him with us.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I am heartily glad the Cur diſlikes my Company; ſince the profit I intend from him binds me from beating him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, where lives the Lady, and what's her name? If we can do you any ſervice, wee're both ready to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Dear Ned, that's kindly ſaid, and like thy ſelf; and you, Franck Friendly?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: It's old Pett's Daughter, the Eaſt India Merchant; he lives at Hackney.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Sir? I doubt I ſhall ſet you beſides the Saddle: This falls out as I could wiſh: This Fool making choice of me to keep him Company, brings me to kiſs the Hand of my fair Miſtreſs, and by that means to manage my affairs as I could wiſh.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Come, will you go, Gentlemen? I and my Man will walk before you, you may eaſily overtake us, for Moſes is as ſtiff as a Tree.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We will not fail to follow you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Lovewell, how lik'ſt thou this? The Fool comes on finely.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have a deſign, Franck, in hand, will make us all men. You know he has made choice of us to be the means to make his Miſtreſs love him. The ſame Lady that he ſpeaks of I have lov'd long; and ſhe has long lov'd me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Dear Ned, proceed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
My fortune being ſpent before I thought on't, my Clothes
decay'd, and having little left me to repair my ruines; all my proceedings ſince have been by Proxy, excepting now and then a ſtoln viſit over the Garden Wall; which lately in attempting, I was taken by her Father, and turn'd out by Grooms; which was the real cauſe of my late melancholy.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Td's death, then wee're undone; he'le know you again, and ſo we ſhall be us'd worſe than you were before.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Thy fooliſh fears, Friendly, have made us fail in many a fair deſign. Do you think the old fellow will know him again that he ſaw before but in half a Peruke, and not Clothes enough to cover him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, Blunderbuſs, he bolts out ſometimes to the purpoſe. I'le undertake, Franck, he knows me no more than I ſhould the Grand Seignior, if I ſaw him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So the young Squire ſhall be at the charge of all Entertainments, till you have found a way to cheat him of his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Right; now let's follow him. But what ſhall we do with this Fellow? I'm certain, ſhould he undertake to walk it, he'le flounder with his flat feet; and we cannot conveniently call for clean Litter for him in a ſtrange Houſe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pox on you for a couple of Puppys; I know you dare not carry me with you, for fear of diſobliging your Bubble. I'le meet you at Night at the Devil Tavern, for the Scene is alter'd ſince the Money came in; as long as that laſts I'le no more of the Can Office.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: A match; ſo God b'uy, blundering Tom.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Farewel, Fopps.

div.head: Scena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Juſtice Frump, Stingey his Clerk, and Goody Fells.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, you are a very fidling Woman, and are alwayes worrying me and my Man for Warrants; what cauſe of Action have you againſt theſe men?

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Why, an't like your Worſhip, I have 'em upon ſuſpitions of perjury. 'Tis well known to your Worſhip that I underſtand the Law; they both ſwore to me ſolemnly by the croſs of a Book, that they would pay me my Money on Monday Morning, and run away on Saturday Night.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: That's right, the perjury lies good in that point. But how do you know they are gone?

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell your Worſhip, without giving your Worſhip the trouble of many words, for your Worſhip knows I am not a Woman of many words: I wiſh I had more, for the good of the poor Pariſh I live in; if I had, I could get Money enough, by teaching of young Maids to talk at the Bake-houſe: for indeed, I help a great many Maids to Services, an't like your Worſhip, that ſometimes are able to give their Miſtreſſes but ſad accounts when they come home.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Pray, Gammer Fells, fall to the buſineſs, and let me know how you are ſure your Lodgers have quite left you; for if they come again, the perjury is void in Law.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Why, then, I'le tell you, Sir; my Maid peep'd through the Key-hole, and ſee 'em put up all their goods in their pockets; and ſhe's without to juſtifie it.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: It's a ſign they had a ſtrong Wardrobe.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Why truly, Gammer Fells, that's a very good proof; Stingey, ſet that down in your Table-Book, that we may make a Preſident of it, for we have many of theſe Myſtical matters come before us; have you any thing more againſt theſe men? for I find the cauſe is foul o' their ſides.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Yes, an't like your Worſhip; they owe me ſeven ſhillings for Rent, beſides ſeven and ſix pence, for waſhing Linnen; and I hope the Law will allow me ſomewhat for the uſe of my own ſhift, I lent Mr. Faithful, whilſt his was waſht; for I can ſwear he wore it out extreamly.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Goody Fells, in that caſe the Law ſomewhat differs. For Littleton ſays, what's lent is lent. But then there is a Statute of fifty ſixth of Queen Elizabeth that makes ſome proviſion in that caſe. Stingey, what is the Statute in that caſe?

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Why, an't like your Worſhip, the Statute of Queen Elizabeth is a Statute in Statu quo; and you know, Sir, that the Engliſh of Statu quo is, what you lend, you loſe. Therefore I'm of Mr. Littleton's mind, that what is lent, is lent.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, this is the very Letter of the Law; you muſt loſe the loan of your ſmock. I, but I'le make 'em ſmoak for the reſt. Have you made the Warrant, Stingey?

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: You muſt give me a ſhilling; Woman.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: With all my heart, an't like your Worſhip; without offence to your Worſhip, I think I know the price of a Warrant, as well as your Worſhips ſelf. I think they are all good, an't like your Worſhip.

div.stage: She ſumbles in her purſe, and pays him in farthings.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Stingey, direct her how to ſerve it.

div.stage: He pulls out his Spectacles, and reades the farthings.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Carry it, Gammer Fells, to Mr. Clowt, the Conſtable; he is a whole-ſale Cobler, and my Maſters near Kinſman; he will be careful, for 'tis of great concern.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Bleſs your Worſhip; good buy to your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Goody Fells, pray do ſo much as change this farthing, I doubt it is not ſo right as it ſhould be.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Mr. Thomas, if you be remember'd, you left a penny Rowl unpaid of your laſt weeks breakfaſts.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Truly, Gammer Fells, I think I did; I'le pay it. Then, Sir, I muſt have but five pence.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: This will prove a crabbed caſe, Stingey; let's go in, and conſider on't: I proteſt, it almoſt confounds me.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Pett, Leticia, Fickle, and Betty.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I wonder Mr. Leftwell comes not.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's one Mr. Leftwell deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Deſire him to walk in. Daughter, remember your Duty, and receive him kindly.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant; I come to kiſs your Hand. Wan't that a-la-mode, Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very well; proceed, proceed.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Sir, I've made bold to bring my Friends.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Mr. Leftwell, they're welcome for their own ſakes, and much more for yours. Gentlemen, you're welcome; pray be pleas'd to ſit down.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, which of theſe three is my Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: This is my Daughter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p:
Faith, Sir, I like this little Gentlewoman as well
To Betty. as her; but your Daughter has moſt Money, I believe; and 'tis that which makes the Mare to go, as the ſaying is.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O this damn'd dogg! the Devil's in him.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Well then, Lady; ſince you are ſhe, let me look upon you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I, pray good Sir, look, before you leap, by all means.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Can you find in your Conſcience to affect me? If you can't, let it alone, I'le look for ſome body elſe; for I ſuppoſe, there will be little love loſt. Let me ſee you look as if you were a little out of your wits. I hear you have a great deal of wit; I'le try you, look upon that Gentleman, he's able to ſay more in half an hour than you can anſwer in ſeven year, as wiſe as you are.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why, has he more wit than you have, Sir?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I, a hundred times, and a hundred to that.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Then I aſſure you he's too hard for me, for I don't know what to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I thought I ſhould put you to't But now I'le deſire Ned Lovewell to take you in hand; you ſhall ſee how much he can ſay more than I; I brought him to make love for me, but i'faith, I think I ſhall ſcarce find work for my ſelf. Ned, prethee lend me your place a little, and take you mine.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir; any thing to ſatisfie you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Mr. Pett, you muſt not be angry, for I am reſolv'd to have your Daughter, whoever I ſpeak to I'le but make a few pretty pretences to the reſt.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I proteſt, a pretty mettle'd man; I like his humour. I, I, Sir, make your ſelf as merry as you can.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Lady, how do you like me?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: So, ſo; you're a pretty kind of a man, but you wear your Clothes to the worſt advantage that e're I ſaw; your Bands are quite out of faſhion. Why don't you wear a Cravat? I fancy 'twould become you prettily, let me tye your Band like one.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Pough, let me alone, you'le all foul it. I hate this fooling: you think waſhing coſts nothing. I never ſaw ſuch a Woman in my life.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Then you ſhould wear a lace about your ſleeves; this makes you look ugly.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I hope a man may look as he will, and wear what he will, for all you; it coſts you nothing.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis nothing to me; but before I would wear ſuch ſhooe-ſtrings, I'de tye my ſhooes with blew tape.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Prethee, Coz, let the Gentleman alone; he wears what likes him.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I'm glad you're come to my relief, I believe I ſhould have loſt all my Clothes elſe. I'le tell you this, Miſtreſs; had you been a Man, I'de a taken you over the face, for all your bravery.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: There's a Clown. I proteſt, Sir, I told him in kindneſs, never let me live elſe.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Let me dye, Madam, if I don't think he deſerves to be hang'd. Was ever ſuch a dirty Raſcal? Ee'ne let him alone, Madam; I would not have you give your ſelf the trouble to laugh at him.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Ned Lovewell, how do you like her? Pray, Sir, let me have her again. Give me your Hand, I'm a Horſe if I dont love you heartily; now do you love me?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: How can I chooſe, Sir? every body muſt love you that looks on you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Then I'le take your Father aſide, and ſatisfie him how I love you, and what I intend to ſettle upon you; and ſo the work ſhall be done, before the World's aware of it. Mr. Pett, I deſire to ſpend half an hour with you in private.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: With all my heart, Sir; wee'le walk in, and return preſently. Gentlemen, you'le pardon us, bus'neſs muſt be done.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, we'le take a walk in the Gallery till you come again.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Do ſo, Daughter.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: This Fool, Leftwell, produces a brave opportunity to bring Mr. Lovewell and my Miſtreſs together; which there had been no way to have done without him; I hope, by this time, the affair is ſo well ſetled, that nothing can fruſtrate it. This Aſſe ſhall never carry her; if he does, both I, and all that are concern'd in the Plot, do undoubtedly deſerve a moſt infamous death.

q.l: In Love's affairs the Womens wits are beſt:
I'le Club my ſhare; let Fortune do the reſt.

div.head: Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Clowt the Conſtable, Goody Fells, and Faithfull.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: A Way with him, away with him; you're my Pris'ner now: I'le have you up for my Rent, Sirrah, and my poor Maids money out of pocket.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Bring him away, Captain Clowt; do you ſee how he laughs at you? Thus he ſerv'd me the very Night he run away with his Clothes. Come, Sir, I'le lend you a hand.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, pray whither muſt I go; and what have you againſt me?

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Why, I have a Warrant againſt you for Felony, and Perjury.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: At whoſe ſuit, in the Devil's name?

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: At this Womans; who is, Sir, as wiſe a Woman as any is in this Pariſh. You had beſt compound the buſineſs, and make the beſt of a bad matter.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, I'le kick —

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: How do you ſay, you'le kick me? kick me, Sir! I'de have you to know I am the Kings Conſtable, and cannot be kickt by any Chriſtian living.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I'le ſwear I heard him ſay he would kick ye; this ſhall come before Juſtice Frump, with the reſt; I warrant thee that it ſhall. You kick a Conſtable of the Kings, and a Captain of the Train'd Bands?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Conſtable, give me leave to ſpeak a little.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: I tell you as I told you before, I am the Kings Conſtable; and 'tis not my place to give people leave to ſpeak that are my Pris'ners. Therefore come on, Sir; I charge you in the Kings name, to come on.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I, I charge you in the Kings Name to come before Juſtice Frump.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Pray, Goody Fells, what Commiſſion have you to command in the Kings name? Are you a Conſtable, Goody Fells? This is very fine, i'ſaith; I'le have that try'd as ſoon as e're we come before my Couſin Frump.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Well, Sir; you're a Captain, and a Conſtable; and a poor Woman muſt not have the liberty before you to be large in her own buſineſs, or elſe I could ſay ſomething. And 'tis not unknown to ſome of the Pariſh, that I underſtand the buſineſs of a Conſtable as well as the beſt Clowt in Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: You underſtand the buſineſs of a Conſtable? Come, I'le put a queſtion to you. Provided, Gammer Fells, that you were upon the Watch, as I was laſt night.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Well; why, what then? Pray ſay on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Well, and you take a Man upon the Watch. And you take a Man upon the Watch, as I ſaid before.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Under favour, Mr. Clowt, you have ſaid nothing elſe to the buſineſs yet.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Very good; The Man being thus taken, falls to play at Putt with one of the Watch-men upon the Watch; and falling to play, they fall out; falling out, they fall together by the ears. Preſently the Watch-man takes me up a brown Bill, and beats me out his brains. Now preſently after, there comes a Tryal between the Man kill'd, and him that kill'd him. Which has the Law o'their ſide? Now, Gammer Fells.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: The Man that was kill'd fell out with him that kill'd him; ſo he that was kill'd, was kill'd Se defeddede; I know what I ſay, Captain Clowt. I ſay Se defeddede; which is to ſay, much againſt his will; therefore the Man kill'd has the right of the Law 'gainſt him that kill'd him.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Well, Gammer Fells, you have done more, I proteſt, than Juſtice Frump himſelf could have done. If my Woman were dead, I would have thee before any Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Land-lady, thou talk'ſt of wit enough for a Conſtable, thou art wiſe enough to make a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Why, Sir, there are ſome Conſtables have as much wit as ſome Juſtices. Pray, Sir, will you walk on, or I ſhall be fain to Command you in the Kings name again.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I, Mr. Clowt, I want my Money; pray let's make what haſte we can.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: We ſhall drink one glaſs of Wine before we go.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: To do you a kindneſs, Sir, wee'le drink one half pint: ſhall we, Gammer Fells? But remember, Sir, you threatned to kick me.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now things are in this poſture, Mr. Lovewell, pray have a care you put not all aſide by your neglect: my Father (I'm afraid) will make all haſte to expedite this Marriage. In having you, I venture all I have, or hope for; therefore have a little care extraordinary for her ſake that loves you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me not live under Heaven's light one minute after I forget the leaſt of your Commands, from whom I've had ſuch honours heap'd upon me. Can you believe I can be ſuch a Slave, as to forget that thing is only able to compleat my happineſs?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I love to hear you ſay you love me, and 'tis becauſe I do believe you do ſo. Yet I am ſad, and ſhall be, till I have eſcap'd the fears I live in, of being forc'd by my too rigorous Father to be fetter'd to this fool of Men.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, when they come back, then we ſhall find how far they have proceeded; by that we may know which way to order our affairs; of which I ſhall not fail by Letters to acquaint you conſtantly.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My Father will have ſuch an eye over me, that I'm afraid I ſhall ſcarce er'e be out of's ſight. He has been ſtrangely Jealous and Inquiſitive e're ſince he ſaw us in the Garden laſt (though now I think he knows you not again) therefore I doubt it will be very hard to have a Letter brought without his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Betty and I have made a bargain will prevent all fear; my Man is to pretend Marriage to her; by which means, he may ſtill find admittance, and make her ſenſible, and ſhe you, of all my Actions, and deſigns: which will be weak indeed, if not able to out-do all that your old Father, and that Young Fool can e're contrive.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I like that well. Now, Couſin Fickle, how do you find the Gentleman? Is he well fitted? Have you look'd over his Linnen?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p:
How do you find your Friend, Couſin Let? Does he woe hard for Mr. Lovewell? I doubt he has been about his own buſineſs,
I ſhould like him the worſe elſe, and forget him (I mean the Fool) that threatned to beat me for adviſing him to wear lace about his ſleeves.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Shall I cut his tongue out for it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake do, Mr. Friendly; I'le love you as long as I live, if you will. I believe, Couſin, my Uncle and he will make the match againſt to morrow Morning, then thou art miſerable: faith, rather then ſo, let's riſe up before he comes. Thou ſhalt Marry Mr. Lovewell, and I'le ee'ne take Mr. Friendly here.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: A match, Couſin Mad-Cap; but I doubt you can't keep your word, nor live ſo long in one mind. I proteſt, if thou ſhould'ſt, I would ſweare thou wert never true to any thing, but Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Dear Madam, let me kiſs this hand for that kind contrivance.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Nay, one ſhan't mock t'other; both, or none, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Both, a thouſand times together; but here they come.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I am ſorry we have made you ſtay thus long, Gentlemen; but Mr. Leftwell and I have done a good work ſince we went: we have ſet an end to wooing. Daughter, you're allow'd but two dayes to prepare for Marriage, and making of Wedding Clothes. I hope theſe Gentlemen will dance at the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I faith, Ned, and Franck, the Lady there muſt Marry me, whether ſhe will or no. Why, you muſt, Miſtreſs, for all you look ſo. You two ſhall be my Bride-men, ſhan't they, Father Pett?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What you pleaſe for that, Son; the Gentlemen look like civil men, and will do very well.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Dinner waits on your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen, will you walk in?

div.head: Scena tertia.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Was ever Man made thus Drunk by a Cuckoldly Conſtable, and an Old Apple-Woman? Captain Clowt, the Kings Conſtable,
lend me your Commanding Staff to lean upon. Let me ſee, you laid out all.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Not all; Gammer Fells paid eleven pence towards the laſt Reckoning.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Captain Clowt, you're a drunken Dog, and I defie you, and there's an end o'th' Story; therefore ſtand further off. What place it this? where are we?

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Why, this is the Worſhipful Juſtice Frump's Houſe; an Honourable Gentleman he is, I hope he'le hamper you, i'faith. If he don't ſet you in the Stocks for being drunk, and put you into Priſon for my Money, he is not the Man I took him for.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
This Old Trot has not drunk her tongue out of rune yet. You Hell-Cat, with your Hoggs face, I'le ſo feague you with this faggot-ſtick.
Enter Stingey. How now, who's this that looks as if he had been got between a ſtarv'd Quaker and a Holy Siſter, behind the door of a Conventicle? Come hither, Sir, let me ſee, is your Noſe made of Cheeſe?

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: O, ſay you ſo, Sir; I ſee, what e're your Noſe is made of, you have a tongue in your Head. What white-liver'd logger-head are you?

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: How now, Couſin Clowt? I ſee you are an honeſt man, and careful in your Office. Is this the Malefactor?

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: An't like your Worſhip, Sir, this is the Man that made promiſe of Marriage to the Maid, borrow'd her Money, cheated the Miſtreſs, wore out her own Shift, now does, or lately did wear out her Husbands Shirt, ſinfully ſwore to pay her her Rent one night, and ſhamefully run away, without any regard to his Oath, the next Morning. There lyes the perjury, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Good Mr. Clowt, give me leave to ſpeak in my own cauſe; I think I underſtand the Law a little better than a Man that has not been above a Moneth in his Office.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, you're a Fool in matters of Law; you know little of that: therefore I ſay, that I ought (being an Officer of State) to have the priviledge of ſpeaking, before any Woman that wears a Head.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Couſin Clowt, go on; let me have a full of the bus'neſs, that I may proceed to Sentence.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p:
Mr. Juſtice, I ſhall wring you by the red Noſe, if you liſten to
that Logger-head any longer, before you hear me ſpeak. Therefore let's have a Bottle of Sack, and ſo conclude the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Bottles of Sack won't pay me my Rent, nor repair my Linnen, nor take up the Perjury; and that's the point I inſiſt upon.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why, you pernicious old Whore you; wherein am I perjur'd?

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: How, de'e call Whore in the face of Juſtice? Gammer Fells, bring your Action, I'le bear you out on't. Sir, I'le tell you the Law as to matter o'that. But hold, let us proceed to the firſt Indictment. Stingey, reade the Indictment.

div.p: YOu ſtand here charg'd, by the name of Thomas Faithfull, at the Suit of Cicily Fells, of the Pariſh of St. Giles's in the Fields, in the County of Middleſex, Widdow; for Perjury, and breach of promiſe to the Maid of the ſaid Cicily, in point of Marriage, and the Sum of ſeven ſhillings, and ſix pence, with lawfull Intereſt and dammages for the forbearance thereof: for Lodging had at the Houſe of the ſaid Cicily; and moreover, in the ſum of ſeven ſhillings of like Money, for Laundry work done by the ſaid Cicily.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, well; I'le pay it all. Little Ananias, you and I will go to a Wench.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let me alone; I am none of thoſe you take me for: I go to a Wench? I'de rather dye than look upon a lewd Woman, in the way of wickedneſs.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Sir, guilty, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Honeſt old Raſcal, do one thing well in thy life, and lend your man Money to go with me, and have a leap; I'le ne're let go his Ear elſe.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Sir, I proteſt, let go my Mans Ear, and plead, or I'le have you preſt.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, let go my Ear, or in earneſt I'le bring my Action.

div.stage: While they talk, Gammer Fells falls aſleep.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, awake, and hear the Judgment of the Court.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Tell not me of Judgment; let me have my Money, and the Man Married to my Maid, the King paid for the Perjury, and Mr. Clowt paid for his pains.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: His Worſhip muſt give Judgment, before the Malefactor can make payment, Gammer Fells.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: I, Goody Fells, pray be patient; fair and ſoftly goes far, they ſay. Sir, you hear that your faults are of a high Nature; I'le tell you the letter of the Law in thoſe caſes you are now accus'd for. Plowden ſays, in his Pleas, and Reports, that, for Perjury, you ought to pay five ſhillings to the Juſtice you are brought before, and half a Crown to his Clerk. For Perjury is, Corpus cum eauſa, by the Statute of the Three and Thirtieth of King James.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Plowden's a Puppy, and you're an Owl; and I'le ſee you hang'd, and the Devil ride your ſtarv'd Clerk Hackney to Hell, before you ſhall have one penny of me. Juſtice, prethee, ſend for a Pint of Wine.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Sir, ask any learned Lawyer about Town, they'le tell you, that Plowden was no Puppy; pray, Sir, pay but me and my Man the Money the Statute allows us, and I'le give you time for the payment of this poor Woman and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Will you, faith, Juſtice Frump? That is fine, Juſtice Frump: ſhall I be fobb'd off now with a promiſe of payment? Did I put my Cauſe into your hands for help, and you to put the perjury Money into your own pocket? are you willing, forſooth, that I muſt lye by the loſs? Is this Juſtice? No, 'tis Jewiſhly done.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To him, Gammer Fells, to him, to him.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, let me have my Money, and I'le take a courſe for yours. Pray, Sir, will you ſatisfie me and my Man, and pay for the Perjury?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Will your Worſhip be pleas'd to hear me?

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: If you have any thing to ſay for your felf, why Sentence ſhould not paſs upon you, pray ſpeak, and remember the payment of the perjury Money. If I han't it, 'tis ſo much Money out of mine, and my Man's pocket, I proteſt to you; and that's all the Woman ſtands upon.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: It's falſe; and your Worſhip is little better than a Lyar in ſaying ſo: 'tis my own Money I want.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Woman, Woman, let your betters be ſerv'd before you.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Mr. Juſtice, you promis'd to hear me ſpeak; pray be as good as your Word.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: You have liberty to ſay any thing, ſo it be to the purpoſe; and pray remember the perjury Money. Woman, you ſhall have ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Then, let but Chitterlin-Chops, your Man, here, go but with me to a Bawdy-Houſe, and I'le ſend you your Money due upon the perjury; my Land-lady ſhall have ſatisfaction, and I'le Marry he Maid. I'le play your Puppy but one hit.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Take your Cloak, Stingey, and go along with the Gentleman; 'tis a caſe of neceſſity, and no ſin; for we ſhall loſe ſeven ſhillings, and ſix pence, elſe; conſider, Stingey, ſeven, and ſix pence, is Money.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Now, I'le ſee you all burn'd firſt, and ſo take your Courſe.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Stingey, make his Mittimus; and away with him, Couſin Clowt.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: I made the Mittimus before, an't like your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Stingey, make him pay for't, and bring me in my part. Couſin Clowt, take care of him; for I'me reſolv'd to hamper him.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Come along, Sir; once more I charge you in the Kings name.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, pay me for making the Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I, Codds head, come hither — Be a good Husband, and keep this till I come again.

div.stage: Gives him a box on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: O Lord, how ſhall I anſwer this to my Maſter?

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Bring him along; I'le never leave you, till I ſee him ſafe.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Pett, Leftwell, Lovewell, Friendly, Leticia, Fickle, Betty, in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I wiſh your Cheer had been better; but expecting none but my Son Leftwell, I have provided leſs than I ſhould have done, had I had warning of your good Company.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, your Entertainment has been like your ſelf, moſt truly generous and Noble.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I vow, Father, I have ſpent a ſhilling many a time for a dinner, between Moſes and I, and have not dyn'd half ſo well.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is a very pleaſant Garden, Sir; and that row of Trees adds much to the beauty of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p:
Sir, I believe 'twould be very pretty, if the Plot were alter'd,
and the Trees taken down at the end, and a gravell Walk made.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: If the Trees were remov'd to day at thy Requeſt, Niece, to morrow thou would'ſt wonder why they were taken down, and be for tranſplanting them again ſome where elſe. I'm confident thou would'ſt not like them half an hour in any place; therefore, prethee leave thy prating.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I perceive by your humming (Mr. Lovewell) you Sing well, therefore let me engage you to give us a Song, whilſt we ſit down in yonder Arbour. Nay, I will not be deny'd; and my Couſin here, in requital, ſhall give you another.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: If you love me, honeſt Ned, do my Miſtreſs that kindneſs. Come, don't be out of Countenance, Man. Why, there's no harm in ſinging in Civil Company; is there, Father Pett?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: No, truly, Son, I think not.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, to ſerve you and your Lady that muſt be, I would ſing till I had loſt my Lungs; but I am ſo unfitting now. Madam, your Ladyſhip muſt undergo the whole brunt of the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Well, Ned, when wee're alone, that word ſhall be ſomething in thy way, I'le aſſure thee, take my word for't; he has a Cold, and can't ſing. Pray ſing you, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, pray oblige us.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, we believe your excuſe juſt, and another time ſhall ſerve.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Honeſt Ned, let me tell thee, thou ſing'ſt as well as any Man in the World, when thou art well; would I were a Woman, for thy ſake. Thou art a ſweet Rogue. Have a kindneſs for him, dear Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ladies, I fear if I had ſung, I ſhould have made your Heads ake, for all Mr. Leftwell's Commendations; but let me beg the performance of your promiſe, Madam.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prethee, let's have the Song you ſung to us laſt night; I like it very well. Come, no excuſes, but do it.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Since, Madam, there's no way to avoyd it, I'le obey your Commands. But I hope, Gentlemen, you'le not be angry with me for making a noiſe.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pretty Miſtreſs, make an end of the Prologue, and come to the matter.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: What ſay you, Gentlemen, how do you approve of my Kinſwomans Voice?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: As I hope to live, Madam, your Voice would invite me from my Prayers to liſten to it, were I ſure not to live above half an hour after.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: P'ſhaw, waw, wherein is her Voice ſo good, as to perſwade you into an Opinion on't; I have heard a Hogg, when a Maſtiff Dog has hung at his Ear, make better Muſick: I wiſh her Song were in her guts, ſo we had one of Ned Lovewell's.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Mr. Leftwell, you do her wrong, to ſay ſhe Sings not well; beſides, it calls your Judgment in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I think I ſhould have as much Judgment in Singing, as another Man, for my Father taught me for two years together; there is not an old Song that ever was made, but I can ſing it.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Leftwell, will you oblige me, and the reſt of the Company, with any one you can conveniently ſpare, now we are in the Singing humour.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: For thy ſake, my Sweet heart that is, and my Wife that muſt be, I will ſing, ſay, or do any thing.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, Sing then; ſhe deſires you that you would.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O good Sir, let's hear your Song.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Not for your ſake, Miſtreſs; for you're to be my Maid within theſe two dayes; and ſhall I do any thing at the requeſt of my own Servant? No, I ſcorn it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But Madam Leticia, your Miſtreſs, and I, your Friend, deſire it; pray, Sir, let's live no longer in Expectation.

lg.l: WHen as King Henry Rul'd this Land,

l.hi: Beſides the Queen, He dearly lov'd

lg.l: Moſt Peerleſs was her, &c.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: No more of your Ballad; I proteſt my brains are ready to ſplit: I had rather be ty'd to a load of Iron, and be drawn after it quite through London, than hear your Servant ſing ſuch another Sonner.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: You're a fooliſh Gitle; this was one of the prettyeſt Songs in London, when I came to Prentice firſt. You don't know what a Song is; Sing on, Son.

l.hi: A Sweeter Creature in the World

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the Song is good, Sir; but Mr. Leftwell's Voice is at preſent, a little out of Tune; and ſo if he pleaſes, wee'le have the reſt another time.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Indeed, I have got a kind of a Cold; but when ever (if thou haſt a mind to hear it) 'tis all at thy Service. When we two are abed together, I'le lull thee aſleep every Night, and wake thee every Morning with my Voice, becauſe I ſee thou delight'ſt in it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Without doubt, as much as I do to hear a little Boy beat upon a Bartholomew Drum.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Father, I muſt be forc'd to take my leave of you; I have a Houſe to Let, in Long-Acre, that calls me away (as a Man may ſay) Nolens, Volens, from you.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Nay, pray, Sir, ſtay, and take a ſmall Supper here too; you and your Friends ſhall be as welcome as I know how to make you; ye ſhall have a good Bed, and clean Sheets; ſo much I dare promiſe you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Nay, if you promis'd a thouſand things, I muſt go when I have buſineſs to do, and there's an end of it; and ſo, your Servant, Sir. Good b'uy, my Dear; prethee don't take on, I'le be here again to morrow morning. 'Tis to no purpoſe to grieve, you'le get nothing by that but your labour for your pains, in a manner. Let me intreat you to take this parting partiently.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, I'le aſſure you I'le keep my heart as whole as I can till I ſee you again.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your Servant; wee'le wait on you to the Door. Sir, I hope you and your Friend will do my Son the kindneſs, to undergo the Office of Bride-men.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, I ſhall be proud to have the honour of ſuch Services.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, I do equally eſteem my happineſs with his; and will not fail to pay my due attendance.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir; may you live long, and happy.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Did you ſee my Man Moſes, Mrs. Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes; he, and old Ralph, were drunk an hour before Dinner; and are gone to ſleep.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Pray, when the Rogue wakes, bid him rowl home after me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Now will I prepare my old Maſter to Licenſe my Young Lover to the freedom of Viſiting me; by which the whole deſign can't chooſe but take effect.

lg.l: Aſſiſt us, Cupid, for thou know'ſt 'tis fit
Beauty, and Youth, ſhould be rewards of wit.

div.head: Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: FRanck, the Fool comes on as I could wiſh; h'as ſent me a Letter, wherein, he ſwears he loves me moſt monſtrouſly: ſome way we muſt find out to get more money from him, the better to enable us to cheat him of his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: My little Mad-Cap ſwears ſhe'le have me at the ſame time when you have yours. And if her kindneſs but continue, I ſhall believe my ſelf a happy Man; for as I live, I love her infinitely. But prethee let's ſee Leftwell's Letter.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: He'le be here preſently, he ſends me word; but ſince you love to reade a well-penn'd Letter, this is it, Sir.

body.p: AFter my hearty Commendations, my love remembred unto you, &c. I deſire that you would prepare your ſelf; and get Franck to do the ſame (viz.) to be my Bride-men; for my Miſtreſs vows ſhe will not have me, unleſs I can get you to be as good as your word. I would not have you fail me, for five hundred pounds; for if you do, I ſhall loſe a Wife worth ten Thouſand. And ſo I reſt

div.p: Here's an Epiſtle, with a pox; did ever man ſee ſuch a Puppy?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But now, ſuppoſe we ſhould pretend our Chambers were robb'd when we went with him to Hackney, of the Money that ſhould have furniſht us with Clothes, and neceſſaries, to have attended at his Wedding. What ſay'ſt? Wilt do well?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By this light, nothing like it; is he to meet you here?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: So the Meſſenger ſaid.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'le immediately put my ſelf into a melancholy poſture; but I'm afraid thou'lt never counterfeit well.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: O! feat not that. Hold, here comes the Cuckco — let's ſeem not to ſee him.

div.stage: They pretend not to ſee him; but walk diſcontentedly over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Why Ned! why Franck! why Franck! why Ned! You ſee I'm not worſe than my word. I'm juſt for Hackney now, the Wedding Clothes are gone before; once more, I beg you not to fail me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I, Sir, would willingly perform what Service my ability can reach to; and ſo, I'm certain, would Franck here; but —

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: But what? why, what's the matter, Man? Why, thou art grievous Melancholy. Prethee, tell me what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, 'twill but trouble you to hear your Friend's miſfortunes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: For my part, Sir, I grieve not at my own, I could laugh at them; but that I ſhould fail you, it makes me almoſt mad.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Ned, tell me what's the matter; I proteſt, you make tears ſtand in my eyes: let me know the cauſe quickly, or I ſhall cry out-right. I would not, I proteſt, for a thouſand pounds, you ſhould fail me; I ſhall loſe ſuch a fortune, I ſhall never have again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That's the greateſt of my grief; that you, my Friend, from whom I have found ſuch favours, ſhould be ſo great a loſer in my ill luck. 'Sdeath, I could kill my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: O, for the love of God, good Gentlemen, as you love me, and as you love your Miſtreſſes, let me know what troubles you; I proteſt, I'le tear my Periwigg to pieces elſe. Ned Lovewell, will you tell me or no? or I will tear.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Dear Friend, put on your Periwigg; to ſee you in this paſſion, adds to my ſorrow; and ſhould I tell you now, I know your good nature would lead you to repair our loſſes, which I hate the very thought of, knowing how far we are already engag'd to your Liberality.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: The Coxcomb, I find, will be wrought upon. Dear diſſimulation, how I love thee!

sp.speaker: Left.
