sp.p: Never ſpeak of that, man; if Money will make up the matter, ne're be melancholy; I have juſt now receiv'd two hundred Guineys for the Fines of four Houſes.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But with what confidence can I do this? Pray, Sir, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: By this hand, either let me know what 'tis that troubles ye, and take my Money to make up the matter, or I'le ne're come near you more, though I know I ſhall loſe my Miſtreſs by it. I thought you had had more kindneſs for me, than to hinder me thus of a Fortune; now you have woo'd her for me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Sir; ſince nothing will ſatisfie you, the caſe is thus. That day we went with you to Hackney, our Lodgings were broke ope, and robb'd of all our lac'd Linnen, and almoſt two hundred pounds beſides; ſo that we ſhall want Money, and all things elſe, to furniſh us to do you Service in that garb we willingly would, had not this ſtrange misfortune hinder'd our Intentions.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: P'ſhaw, and is this all? Look, here's all the Money I have about me: I'le ſend Moſes home for more.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Alas, dear Sir, half this will ſerve; pray pardon me: but ſince you'le have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Why ſhould it not be ſo? I ſay, it ſhall be ſo. Go home, Moſes, fetch the Purſe that lyes behind the Cabinet. I'le away to Hackney; you'le come on Thurſday, before nine a Clock.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, wee'le be there before you are up, I warrant you. I do aſſure you I know not what to ſay, that may in the leaſt make ſatisfaction for ſo great a favour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, I am equally unhappy in the want of words, to expreſs my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Pugh, I can't Complement; you have got it, and much good may it do you; and ſo farewell.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Dear Ned, let me ſpit in thy Mouth for thy Ingenuity; faith, 'twas very well done.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: As I live, it went againſt my Conſcience all the while I was about it; and I ſtrangly wonder I went ſo well through with it, to wheadle a Man out of his Money, and cheat him of his Miſtreſs too; 'tis enough to damn an honeſt Man to do it, and make a wiſe Man mad to undergo it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
'Twere honeſt in no caſe but this; for this is but eaſing of
a Brute with half a Soul, of a few of his Fathers ſins; and beſides, if we get theſe Fortunes, we may pay him his Money again. Then, for his Miſtreſs (if ſhe were his, as ſhe's yours) you do a deed of Charity, to preſerve her from being bound to a Fool; beſides—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Enough, enough, Franck; theſe Reaſons are ſufficient to reſettle my ſtruggling Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But now, what's to be done, as to the Ladies? they live in expectation of relief from us; and I long to know a way to ſend it them.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I've made Runwell our Agent here; and we ſhall have by him the Courſe we are to ſteer. The Ladies will give full directions by him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Friend, lyes your bus'neſs with any here?

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.p: I have a Letter for one Mr. Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I am the Man; whence comes it?

sp.speaker: Meſs.
sp.p: The Letter, Sir, will give you ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis Faithful's Character, I think.

body.p: WHen this Letter finds you, come to my Relief as ſoon as you can; for I am cram'd into a little Room in New Priſon, where I am like to be over-run with Lice, and ſtifled with ſtinking Tobacco. Tell Franck Friendly, that I was taken upon a Warrant, at the Suit of our Landlady Fells, for Rent; and committed by one Juſtice Frump: but the Keeper ſayes, hee'le let me out upon any Bail; provided, I pay my Fees. So fail not, dear Friend, with all ſpeed, to reſcue

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O that damn'd Juſtice! he once committed me, for piſſing under his Window.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prethee, Franck, leave prating; and let's haſte, to help the poor Rogue.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a Toothleſs Trot, as this? who the Devil put it into her mind? But let's ſtay no longer.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Couſin Fickle, there is nothing in the World makes me admire more, than to ſee thee ſo long in one mind; that thou ſhould'ſt love one Man two dayes together, is little leſs than a Miracle.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: And nothing but a Miracle can make me miſs him, as we have laid the Plot. If they come according to our appointment, wee'le be Married two hours before my Uncle, and the intended Bride-groom, are awake; but ſhould I miſs him to Morrow, I'de have him the next place I meet him in. My Uncle cannot hinder me, though he may you; nor ſhall, from marrying any Man that I affect.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O Coz, that I were but in thy Condition; and as free from the fear of a Father! but I Vow, my heart begins to fail me; if we play this trick to Morrow, when he miſſes us, hee'le certainly run ſtark mad; and turn me off, without a penny Portion.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Dear Girle, fear not that; he may be angry for a Moneth, or ſo, but no longer; for he has never another Child. Nature will engage him to come about again, and give thee all; hee'le be as kind as ever, never fear it. However, wilt thou weigh thy Fathers anger, in compariſon, with the loſs of gentile Mr. Lovewell? Let me dye, if I am not aſhm'd to ſee thee have ſuch idle fears.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: The Scene is ſtrangely alter'd; when thou com'ſt to counſel any body to Love and Conſtancy; but Coz, doſt think thou canſt continue this humour, till to Morrow?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Leave your tatling; for I queſtion your reſolution more than you need mine; I could find in my heart not to let you go to Bed to Night, leſt you ſhould lye too long in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Nay, I will never be out-done by thee, in point of promiſe; I will be up, and ready to meet him; go, and be immediately Married to him, though I turn Seamſtreſs for my Living. Therefore come along, Girle.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Said like thy ſelf, ſweet Coz; if it be done to Morrow, wee'le laugh one Day, let what will follow.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
Have you fully inſtructed Betty, that ſhe may ſatisfie Mr. Lovewell's Man, the time and place they are to meet us in? You
know I left all that to your care: has ſhe the Letter for him?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: To th' full, fear not: let's in, and put our Jewels up; for if the Old Man proves unkind, they may ſtand thy Friends; I'm ſure he muſt pay me my Portion.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Mr. Runwell, I have got ſuch a bundle of bus'neſs here will make you mad to carry it, and your Maſter mad with joy to hear it. Tell him, and Mr. Friendly, that the Ladies deſire their Companys by four a Clock to morrow Morning, at the corner of our back-gate, with a Coach. But here's two Letters, which if you give your Maſters, will ſave you the trouble of telling a long Story. So pray be careful, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: Mrs. Betty, Mrs. Betty; unleſs you pity me, my Maſter has utterly undone me.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter, man?

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: Here he has ſet me to wooe in jeſt, and I'm in love in earneſt. Unleſs you think you can love me, I am bound to wiſh I had never ſeen you; for I find in my ſelf I cannot live without you.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O, if that be all, leave it to me; and as I find your care in your Maſters concerns, ſo you ſhall find my love towards you, if you are in earneſt. Fare you well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: This is ſhort, and ſweet; it ſavours ſomething of kindneſs: but what I ſhould do with a Wife if I had one, I can no more tell, than a Taylor knows how to make a Horſe-ſhooe. And yet I love this little Rogue ſo well, that I muſt have her, though Ruine were ſure to follow: however I hope my Maſter, when he has got his Miſtreſs, will help us out at a dead lift. But I muſt make haſte.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Ho! where are you Ralph? is the Cook come?

sp.speaker: Ralph.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Bid him come to me; Betty, do you get Mrs. Snuff, the Houſe-Keeper, to make the Wedding Bed, ſhe knows what belongs to ſuch matters; and look that the Hangings in the Matted Room be bruſht down, and the Chare-Woman rub the reſt of the Rooms. Let every thing be done in Order.

Pray, Mr. Lard, look that every thing you undertake be done decently; ſpare for no coſt, but call for every thing you want. I would not be niggardly at the Wedding of my only Child. Has Mr. Plume, the Poulterer, ſent the Cram'd Capons, the tame Pidgeons, and the Partridges. And, Betty, ſtep to the Butler, and ſee whether he has Bottel'd the two Tearces of Claret, and the half Pipe of Canary. Pray look about you, and let every thing be done that may adorn the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Sir, let me have but Meat enough, and things convenient to carry on the work of the day, if I don't lick my fingers after the French Mode, and make ſawce as well as any Man of my Profeſſion, let me be put into Pye-Cruſt, and ſent a Sacrifice to the unappeas'd Stomacks of unſatiate Serving-men.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Sir, I'le ſee that every thing be ready to your ſatisfaction, as far as I'm concern'd, and look that the Bride be dreſt before Eight of the Clock, or the Cook ſhall cut me into Steaks and Stew me.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: God-a-mercy, good Girle; get thee about thy buſineſs then, for thou haſt a great deal to do.
Mr. Lard, queſtion not but you ſhall have every thing, to furniſh out a Feaſt for the Entertainment of a King. Command what's neceſſary for the Kitchin.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Let me alone, then; I'le warrant your Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Father; pray, how does your Head?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Very well, Son; pray, why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Only to be ſatisfy'd, Sir, becauſe mine akes, and turns round, as if 'twere about to look for another ſeat, and would take leave of my ſhoulders; why, there is not a pair of hands in the Houſe but what's in motion, to make as much noiſe as they can; all the great Guns in a Sea-fight ſing treble, in compariſon of the Thundring baſe that Reigns in every Room here. Pray, Sir, what's your deſign in this? Do you intend to make me mad before I'm Married?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: No, Sir; but I have a deſign to have my Houſe ſet in Order, and to make proviſion for thoſe that ſhall entertain you and your Bride to Morrow; and do you think this can be done without noiſes? I warrant you would have had the Victuals ſent to the next door to be dreſt, and ſo brought through the Street to the Table. Pray, Son, if the noiſe be ſo troubleſome to you, let you and I go to the back-ſide of the Houſe, and play a game at Tables; are you for Iriſh, or Backgammon?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have ſworn never to throw a Dye more, though I have plaid at Dublits, and loſing Lodum, before now; but I have quite left off Gaming. I care not, if I go up ſtairs, and ſee my Miſtreſs; A Man goes in danger of his life here below: I, by chance, look'd but into the Kitchin, and one of the Cooks took me for a Calf, I believe; and in ſpight of my teeth would needs ſpit me. Then my ſhins have been broke three times to day, by ſtragling Stools that ſtept out of the places they ſtood in this ſeven years, and lay now where I never look'd for 'em. I had like to have had my face waſht too, by the Fellow that cleans the Wainſcoat; his Cloath was within an ace of my Noſe.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Well, Son, there is no help for theſe things; but ſince you have made choice of your Miſtreſs for your Protectreſs, you may find her, and my Niece Fickle, together at the Chamber at the end of the long Gallery.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Lovewell, Friendly, Faithfull, Squeeze the Gaoler, as in a Priſon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How now, Tom, Revelling?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: O, are you come? By your favour, fellow Pris'ners, I muſt ſpoil the Dance.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Garry this Crown to the poor Pris'ners; farewell, Friend. Are you fully ſatisfy'd?

sp.speaker: Squeez.
sp.p: He is diſcharg'd, and may go when he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Lord, Ned, how this Fellow looks! Let me ſee, what does he look like?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, faith, he looks like a poor Whore, turn'd out of an Inns of Court, half drunk, at four a Clock in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Or like a Gipſie, that has been let down a Chimney, and drawn up again with a Gammon of Bacon at her Breech.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why, Gentlemen, had you been where I was, it would have made you look a little uglier than ordinary.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: If thou wert but a little uglier than ordinary, as thou ſay'ſt, a man might endure to look on thee, Tom; but, as I live, thy Face looks juſt of the colour of a Red-herring, and thy hands like a Saylers, that have been ſteept two dayes in Tarr and Tallow. And any body will ſwear, by thy Linnen, thou haſt robb'd a French Lacquey.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This Fellow ſtinks ſo of Tobacco, that there is no way to make him ſmell ſweet, and look like a man, but to take him down to the Thames, and have him drawn twice, or thrice, croſs the Water at the tail of a Sculler.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Say you ſo, Signior Snowt? if you bee'nt ſmoak-dry'd in the ſame place before you have waſht your Hands for to morrow's Dinner, I'le be bound to hang for you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, was there ever ſuch a ſimple ſot as thou art? To have money in thy pocket, and be ſent to Priſon for fourteen ſhillings: Why the Devil did you not pay it? but it may be you had a mind to ſee the Lodging you muſt laſt live in.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p:
If you had given her the money, ſhe had no more to do with you; one would imagine you want brains as well as money; but
perhaps you've a fancy to be lowſie: But wee'le let that paſs. Look, here's more money, Tom.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What, from the ſame hand, Ladds?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is nothing; there is that in hand will make us all happy:

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If that which is in hand won't, I don't know what will: come, what deſigns have you, let me know all?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Come, wee'le truſt you for once; we two are to be married to morrow to two of the greateſt Beauties and Fortunes within twenty miles.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Where, and to whom, dear Rogues, tantalize me no longer?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I don't know yet my ſelf; but here comes one, I believe, will better inform me; what news, Runwell?

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: Sir, I muſt have leave to take breath, before I can tell my tale; you muſt be by four a Clock to morrow morning, and Mr. Friendly with you, at the Corner — But here's a Letter will fully inform you; and here's one for you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By this hand, Franck, I'm afraid to look into mine, leſt there ſhould be leſs in it than I expected.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'm under the ſame ſence of fear; prethee, Ned, open thine, and put me out of pain.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis better to know a man's Fate, than fear it: I'le venture.

body.p: BE ſure you fail not to meet me, and Mr. Friendly my Couſin Fickle, at the Corner of our Garden in the green Meadow, about four of the Clock to Morrow Morning: Provide your Parſon ready at ſome Church in London, that may do the bus'neſs, without delay. My Conſin is as well reſolv'd for Mr. Friendly, as I am for you.

postscript.head: Poſtſcript.
postscript.p: Pray ſend back your Man, that he may be with Betty; ſo if the bus'neſs ſhould fail, he may be able to help us.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Mine is, Franck, as I could wiſh; how ſounds thine?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There's all the harmony of love in't; but Ned, what ſhall we do for a Levite?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Leave that to me; I'le provide Old Legit, the Reader, who is in Orders, and will do the bus'neſs as faſt as a Biſhop, and tye you together to Eternity. And I can borrow the Keyes of the Sexton of St. Giles's for leſs than five ſhillings, and a full Flaggon of mild Beer. Therefore bear up, Boys.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You're ſure you can do this; if you fail us, wee're all undone.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Conſider, Tom, our bus'neſs is your own; for as the caſe ſtands with us, ſo it does with you; either happy, or miſerable.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Trouble your ſelf no further; if I fail, one of you ſhall have my Ears, and t'other my eyes. So farewel, Friends; I'le about it inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Run you back to Betty, and ſtay there till you hear from me.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: I flye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Franck, go you and provide the Coach, and I'le make every thing elſe ready: meet me to night at the Devil Tavern, there wee'le ſtay till two a Clock, and ſo ſet forward.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'le not fail.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I ſhould take it very kindly, Mr. Leftwell, if you would go now, and give me leave to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Your Bride will never get up to morrow morning to be married, if you keep her up ſo late to night. Pray, Mr. Leftwell, leave us.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I won't go till I pleaſe: may'nt I do what I will, if I have a mind to't, with my own Wife? I believe my Father would give me leave to lye with her to night, if I askt it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: What, before you are married? That would be a ſight worth ſeeing indeed. I'faith, if you won't go down, Mr. Leftwell, I ſhall make bold to beat you down with the Bed-ſtaffs: What, I'm ſure my Old Maſter did not ſend you up to day at Noon, to ſee us a bed. Will you be gone, and give my Miſtreſs leave to go to Bed? I ſhall beat you down with the Bed-ſtaff elſe.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p:
Hold •
Betty, don't beat him, wee'le perſwade him civilly. Pray, Mr. Leftwell, be Civil, and do not undertake to ſtay longer, where it cannot be allow'd of with modeſty.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, is your Stomack ſo great, that you can't ſtay till to morrow Night, and ſo take lawful Poſſeſſion? but preſs in in an illegall manner into a place a day before you have a priviledge. I aſſure you, the World will think you want wit ſtrangely in attempting it.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p:
Well, if I don't go down, and do your Etrand to my Father, Miſtreſs, let me live lowſie, and dye upon a Dung-hill. For your part, I ſhall turn you out of Service to Morrow
To Betty. night, like a ſawcy Slut as you are. And I'le beat your ſweet-heart, till his bones rattle in his skin: I ſwear by my Sword, I'le ſqueeze him like a Turnip between two Trenchers; and there's a word for all.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now hee's gone, let's not trouble our ſelves to talk of him, but make proviſion for the Morning's Adventure. 'Tis now almoſt twelve, and you know they'le be at the back-gate by four a Clock in the Morning; and ſhould we ſpend that time idly, 'tis ten to one, but it may bring us to repentance, by unkindly failing our Gallants. Therefore let's fall to packing up thoſe little things we have, to help us in neceſſity; then ſleep an hour or two.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I proteſt, I'le not go to Bed for all the World; if I do, I ſhall certainly loſe my Lover, I alwayes wake ſo late a mornings. But if Betty will ſit up, and promiſe to wake us, wee'le lye down in our Night-Gowns till that time.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: With all my heart, Madam; I'm an errant Slut, if I would not, to promote this buſineſs, ſit ſix dayes, and as many nights, up to the Chin in Water, this cold Weather. For I have ſuch a Faith in both the Gentlemen, that I am very confident they'le make you happy.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Betty, thou ſhalt not fail to ſhare in my good fortune; and now go to your own Chamber, and be ſure to call us in time. You know what you have to do; ſtay behind with Runwell, and be the firſt that miſſes me; and do it with all the paſſion imaginable; ſo you'le be unſuſpected.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Madam, I had rather puniſh my ſelf in being abſent from you (ſince 'tis your command) than be wanting in any Service I may poſſibly do you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: That's my good Girle; but let me kiſs thee firſt for good lucks ſake.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Good night, good Ladies.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Now, Couſin, we're alone, what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Let's ſleep two hours, and riſe before the Sun.

div.head: Scena prima.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: COachman, ſtay you there, ſtir not till we come back. 'Tis devilliſh dark, Ned; not ſo much as a Star ſtirring.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And cruel cold, Franck; if my love wan't very hot, 'twould ne're hold out the battery of this bitter Morning. If the poor Ladies are abroad, I'm ſorry for them, I fear it bites them ſeverely. Prethee where art? canſt thou not keep cloſe?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, I am by you here; but know not in what place.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, I thought I ſmelt you; but come nearer, I'le be a little unkind to my Noſe, and keep you Company at preſent, for want of a ſweeter. But hold, I think, wee're near the place appointed: prethee, come up; is not that the Garden Wall?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You may as well perſwade a blind man to do you the kindneſs, to draw your Picture, as to ask my opinion now; for I can no more ſee thy hand, than I can my own face; nor canſt thou ſee any thing, unleſs thou haſt chang'd eyes with a Cat. But heark, I hear ſome body, and ſee a light yonder.

div.stage: Enter the other way, Leticia, Fickle, and Betty.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Cupid be kind to you, and lend you a lanthorn, 'tis cruel dark: good Ladies, keep your Gowns cloſe about you, for I fear youl'le catch cold.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p:
Faith, Couſin, I'm afraid to ſtir; would they were come,
I have got the Cramp in every one of my fingers, with cold; if I ſtay here but half an hour, I ſhall be fitter for burying than Marriage: I'm afraid I ſhall loſe the finger the Parſon is to put the Ring on. Pray Betty, which finger is that?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Nor I; if I did, I would be ſure to keep that from the cold. Couſin Let. thou look'ſt ſo pitifully, for want of thy Morning's Poſſet, that, o'my Conſcience, I could cry for thee. Give me thy hand, where is it, Girle? Take comfort, I warrant they come.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I dare ſwear 'tis they; let's go a little nearer.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Art ſure there's never a Ditch in the way? Would we had the Women, and were well in the Coach again: But give me thy hand, and I'le go with thee.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I vow, Couſin, my courage was almoſt cold; but to ſee thee ſo confident in thy ſufferings, or indeed, to do thee Juſtice, ſo conſtant; I now believe it a meer ſhame to come ſhort of thee. Whatever happens, I'm reſolv'd to ſtay here till they come, not to be unfix'd in my Reſolutions.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Poor Miſtreſs, I ſhould queſtion the Juſtice of the gods, ſhould they forget to be your Friends, and fail to help you; nay, I ſhould think they had forgot to further goodneſs, if they ſhould let you be a loſer, in proſecution of ſo pure a love.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Never fear, Betty, wee'le through now, though froward Fate had ſworn to ſet a ſtop to it. But heark, I hear the ſteps of ſome body: would I knew who they were; it ſtartles me.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: O, Coz, now thou art faint-hearted again; 'tis nothing but the leaves of the Trees that hang over the Garden Wall. Let's walk a little further forwards.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There's a Candle, Lovewell; let's look a little nearer: ſtay, is not that Leticia?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And I am monſtrouſly miſtaken, if that ben't thy Miſtreſs, and Betty that holds the light; look, they come nearer.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I think I heard ſome body ſay, Leticia: and I begin to loſe my fear, and will look a little further. Betty, light hither a little.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam, the Candle's out, I'm undone. I ſhall never find the way back to the Gate upon the Cawſey.

div.stage: They come up to them in the dark.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, Leticia, Lady; here's no body anſwers. Franck, art ſure 'twas they?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, it may be we ſaw Angels in their ſhapes; 'twas either the one, or the other, I can aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: No, my dear Lovewell; 'tis too late to keep at diſtance, when there lacks ſo little time to make us one; here's ſhe that loves thee; and if Heaven were pleas'd to lend us light, would joy to look on thee.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sweeteſt Leticia, why art thou ſhrowded in this ſheet of darkneſs, that ought to fear, and flye from ſuch a Face, though it preſumes on all the earth beſides? Speak but once more, that I may find thee by thy Voice; ſince my eyes are unſerviceable.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ned, Ned, have you found your Miſtreſs? If you have, lend me your hand to find mine; for I dare as well be hang'd, as ſtir a foot further than the place I'm in: I'm juſt now up to the belly in the Horſe-pond.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Hold, Mr. Lovewell, let me call her: Coz, Coz.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Lord, where are you? I hear Mr. Friendly make ſad complaints, but I proteſt I don't know where to find him. Are you hereabouts, Couſin?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: I, where is your hand?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Here, and here's Betty's; I am glad I have found you: Mr. Lovewell, your Servant; if you would ſpeak, I ſhould be glad to hear you, for I proteſt, I cannot ſee you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, your moſt humble Servant; I would Franck Friendly were as near you as I am: poor Rogue, he lyes poring up and down in the dark for you; Franck, Franck.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here, here, at hand; is my dear Miſtreſs near thereabouts?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: She's here, with Madam Let. and Betty. Thou art the only loſt Sheep of the Company; here, have a care, thou wilt blunder over ſome body; prethee, be careful, take me by the hand.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I ſhould be happy if I had it; hold, is not this it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What do you think?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, I don't know very well; but I'le feel for the Roman T. that will ſatisfie me the truth on't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: One would have thought the ſpirit of Jokeing had been drencht out of you in the Horſe-pond; but here's the hand of your fair Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I, here's a hand indeed, makes me forget all wet and cold, and fear of future Storms.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p:
But if you ſtay much longer here in your wet Breeches,
you'le remember wet and cold again, in ſpight of your Antidote; and I'm ſo wet with dew, that unleſs you make haſte, I ſhall dye before I'm Married; and ſo be put upon ugly work in the other World; you have heard the Proverb: and beſides, you will loſe my Portion, which is no poor one.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Prethee, dear Coz, let's ſtand no longer in the cold tatling of Eſtates, but haſte to the Coach; have you brought one?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I, and four Horſes, that will hurry us to London; and a Levite that will do the buſineſs: we ſhall be there by five a Clock.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I, but we ſhall not get into the Church ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The Sexton has provided a Bottle of Wine, and ſome other things, for your diverſion, till ſeven a Clock, at which time you will be miſt here, and the work will be doing there.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Let's away to the Coach then. Betty, 'tis ſomething lighter now, you may eaſily find the way back; and be ſure you remember your inſtructions, you know where to ſend to me; ſo fare thee well, good Girle.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: I vow, Madam, I muſt weep at parting, though you are going about to do that buſineſs I have alwayes wiſhed you; but aſſure your Ladyſhips, I'le ſerve you both to the utmoſt of my power; and ſo the god of Love preſerve and proſper your proceedings.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Friend. Pretty Mrs. Betty, your Servants.

div.head: Scena ſecunda.
div.stage: Enter Gammer Fells, Clowt, and Mold the Sexton.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I charge you, Neighbour Mold, make a Confeſſion before Mr. Clowt, the Kings Conſtable, of what you told me laſt Night, as you and I ſat in the Chimney Corner at my Houſe, drinking a dram or two of Brandy; by the ſame token, you took the Bottle out of my hand, whilſt I did ſomething; but that's no matter.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p:
Neighbour Mold, diſcharge the part of a good Chriſtian, and clear your Conſcience, by making your Confeſſion to a Conſtable of the Kings; who is a Member of State. Indeed you may object, though I am one of the Kings Conſtables, you are one of his Sextons too; true, it is ſo; and that is in part ſatisfaction: for it is unnatural
for one Member to perſecute another: ſo, if the buſineſs were only 'twixt you and I, 'twere eaſily made up. But here's my Neighbour Fells, truly, a Woman that underſtands the World, has been wickedly dealt with, has a great deal of Money due to her, and much linnen worn out; has lain long in wait for one of the Men, that ſhe ſayes, nay, ſhe ſwears, Neighbour Mold, you told her was to come to your Houſe this Morning, from thence to go to Church to be Married. Therefore I command you in the Kings Name to ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Or elſe I'le have a Petition, to have you before Juſtice Frump.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: How, a Petition, Gammer Fells? you have forgot all your Law, as if you had never had any. A Suppina, Woman, a Suppina; that's the only way. A Petition? I cannot forbear laughing; I tell you, you cannot do it any other way, but by a Suppina. Ha, Gammer Fells, you have not ſo good a Head-piece as you had formerly. Well, well; Age, Age.

div.stage: Enter Lovewell, Friendly, Leticia, and Fickle.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now, my dear Miſtreſs, we are ſafe from all our fears; this is the Sexton's Houſe, there wee'le repoſe a little, then to Church.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Are you come, i'faith, Sir; Seize on him, Mr. Conſtable, in the Kings Name; this is the other Rogue, that ow'd me Money, and forſwore himſelf. Come, bring them all away: for, Mr. Clowt, if one body in a Company be perjur'd, all the reſt are guilty, and muſt ſtand in the Pillory with him.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, 'tis very true, you're in the right in that caſe; ſo I command you all, in the Kings Name, to come away with me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Miſtreſs, if any body here owes you any thing, I'le pay you preſently five times as much, if that will be any ſatisfaction; pray, put us to no trouble, for wee're about earneſt buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: You ſay honeſtly, Sir; pray be as good as your word, and let me have but thirty ſhillings, and I'le diſcharge you; for I love a Gentleman, as I do my life.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Here's your Money; ſo fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold; how ſhall I be diſcharg'd by the King for the perjury? You muſt go fore Juſtice Frump, and ſtand the Tryal.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, who in the Company is perjur'd? Pray, Mr. Conſtable, ben't ſo impertinent, but let us go about our buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Why, that is that Gentleman; and you being in his Company, are, with all the reſt, equally concern'd. So I command you come away, in the Kings Name.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: That's true indeed, the perjury is not diſcharg'd; bring them away, there's no remedy; I would it were in my power to do you any good: Come, Neighbour Clowt, bring 'em along; I'm afraid you'le lye by't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'le not go along with you, not ſhall any of the Company. This Old Bawd has couzen'd me of ſome Money, and I believe you intend to cheat me of more.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: Offer to draw, I'le knock down your Wench here; will you come on quietly, in the Kings Name?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, here's five pounds, let us but paſs now; and wee'le promiſe to meet you to Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I wiſh he would, i'faith; if he takes it, I ſhall tell Juſtice Frump, and ſee how he'le take it; perhaps he'le cheat the King too. Come, come, Mr. Clowt, the Law lyes not in your Hands; if I live, I'le ſee 'em laid up; and if you don't look to your Office, look to your ſelf; ſhall People be perjur'd, and go unpuniſhed?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Why, good Woman, what are you concern'd? your debt is ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Is it ſo, Goody Gillyflurt, with your face full of patches? you ſhall know that I am not ſatisfy'd; 'tis ſuch as you make poor Men they can't pay their Debts: where have they pickt up you and that Puppet, your Companion? I'le have you where you ſhall give an account of your ſelves, and what buſineſs you have with theſe Men.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You abominable old Bawd, I'le kick you, till you curſe your own Blaſpheming tongue.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: How? Do you kick an Antient Houſe-Keeper before the face of me the Kings Conſtable? Sir, I would have you to know, you have forfeited your foot by the Laws of the Land, therefore look to't. Neighbour Mold, I command you in the Kings Name to aſſiſt me; have a good heart, Gammer Fells, I'le ſee you ſatisfied. Come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ned, wee're utterly undone if we go before the Juſtice, for hee'le be ſure to commit us, right, or wrong, if it be but to get his Man Money for the Mittimus; of which he himſelf has the largeſt ſhate.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I don't know what to do. Mr. Conſtable, will nothing ſatisfie you, unleſs we go before the Juſtice; you would do us a favour, if you would take our words till to Morrow; and heark you, Sir, here's five pounds to buy your Wife a Ring.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, I would do it, though you had kill'd my Father, for ſo much Money; but Gammer Fells will have a fling at my Plumb-Tree, and utterly undo me, therefore I cannot do it: Pray, Sir, come along.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Conſtable, will you allow the Ladies liberty to go to a Friends Houſe, whilſt we go to the Juſtice's.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: The Ladies, with a Murrain; no, Sir, they ſhall go with you, and ſee how they like lying in a Gaol. Captain Clowt, come along, I'le lead the way, therefore look to the Pris'ners.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, there's no remedy; Ladies, don't be dejected though; Juſtice muſt diſcharge us.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I do'nt care if the deed be done before my Uncle hears of it. You may go; Mr. Conſtable, wee'le follow you.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Mr. Conſtable, if you deſign our March much further, pray let's have a Coach, for the Ladies are not us'd to foot it ſo far.

sp.speaker: Clowt.
sp.p: This is the Houſe, Sir; pray be patient, I'le have you no further.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Good Morrow, Mr. Clowt; I ſuppoſe, by the people you have brought with you, your buſineſs is to my Maſter; I'le ſtep in, and call him; Mr. Clowt, in the mean time, pray be careful of the Pris'ners.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What peaking Puppy's this, that looks as if he quarter'd with a Camelion, and eat nothing but Air?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: By this light, he looks like one that was got by a Beggar, and has liv'd ever ſince lowſie. But who's this that looks ſo like a Knight Templar, with his Chopps muffled?

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Stingey, the Speech I have been getting by heart theſe ten dayes will now do me a kindneſs to this Company; therefore do you hold the Paper, whilſt I ſpeak; if I chance to be out, you may put me in with a whiſper, and pretend buſineſs; for it is excellent good, and well penn'd by a Counſel learn'd in the Law; and now I'le begin. Hum, ha. Gentlemen, I know not what you are, nor from whence you come; you may be this, or you may be that. But for this or that, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: How, an't like your Worſhip, no matter? your Worſhip ſhall know that the matter is conſiderable, both to the King, and to your ſelf, for all theſe People are perjur'd; and you know by that there's many a penny coming in. And they came from Hackney, and theſe Wenches belong to Mr. Pett, of the ſame Town; and I have ſent him word of it, and he'le be here preſently, I preſume, under favour of your good Worſhip.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Woman, hold your prating, or I proteſt, I'le ſet you into the Stocks; would her tongue were out, ſhe has put me quite beſides my Speech; where abouts was I, Stingey?

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Why, you were at, But for this, or that, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Then, Gentlemen, But for this, or that, it is no matter; as I was ſaying before. You know the time of a Juſtice of Peace is precious, an Antient Author ſayes, concerning the life and living of Juſtices; who ſayes, their labour is much, and their care great: therefore I command you, Gentlemen, and Gentlewomen, that you do not weary me with long Circumſtances, to unſettle my head, but I pray be ſatisfy'd, and ſubmit to Juſtice; for your offences are of a fearful — What's next, Stingey?

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Conſequence.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Of a fearful Conſequence; and indeed, moſt crying Crimes, as the learned Felton ſayes, Libera nos Domine. But let him ſay what he will, he was a Juſtice; I am one, and have in this Houſe the Kings Commiſſion that made me ſo.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I believe your Worſhip's a little miſtaken; ſure, Sir, Mr. Felton was a Parſon, and not a Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p:
Come, come, let me tell you, there is no difference between 'em, learn that from me. You're a Young Man, & have not ſeen ſo
much of the World as ſome have. But, as I was ſaying before, I am a Juſtice, and have the Kings Commiſſion for it.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Juſtice Frump, your Servant; I'm glad to ſee you, Sir, and have made haſte to do it. Gentlemen, you have done kindly by me, I'm beholding to you; ſo is my Son Leftwell here. For your parts, Gentlewomen, you ſhall along with me again. Good Woman, come and Dine with me on Sunday, I'le give you ſatisfaction for your care. Hereafter I ſhall watch you both a little better.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: You are an honeſt Gentleman, Sir, and I'le be ſure to come according to my promiſe; I'm glad that it came into my heart to hinder theſe ſweet pretty Gentlewomens marriage with theſe beggarly Fellows.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Beggarly enough a Conſcience, good Woman; they were not ſo well clad as Adam in Paradice, before I lent 'em Money to make 'em Clothes; no, not ſo much as Figg-leaves, Gammer Fells: and theſe wretched Raſcals, to reward me, come betimes in the Morning, and run away with my Miſtreſs, juſt when I ſhould have married her; no Devils would have done ſo.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: O wicked Knaves; I warrant you, Sir, Juſtice Frump will give them their Reward for it; to go to cheat ſuch a pretty, ſweetfac'd, likely, hopefull, young Gentleman as you are.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Mr. Juſtice, your Servant. Daughter, and Neice, you have deceiv'd me once; but if ever you put ſuch a trick upon me again, I'le forgive you.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Mr. Pett, I ſhould be glad, if the Law would give me leave, to let your Relations go; but they are equally concern'd with theſe Gentlemen, and muſt go with them to New Priſon: 'tis pity, becauſe they are pretty Maids; but Juſtice muſt not be ſtifl'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, wee'le give you ten ſhillings, if you'le ſay you miſtook the Man; and that this is not he: you will get nothing by keeping of us, nor will Mr. Pett know how to get off his Daughter and Couſin; ſo you'le loſe your reward there too.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: I'faith I'le do't, for I love a Gentleman as I do my life.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Sir, I'le be bound to ſave you harmleſs; and I'le ſtay at my London Houſe this Moneth, where you may ſend for me at any time: and here's ten ſhillings for your Clerk.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: There is five for me.

sp.speaker: Fells.
sp.p: Sir, your Worſhip, I proteſt, I miſtook the Man, this is none of him, I thought it was; and unleſs you ſet them all free, I'm undone; they'le ſue me, they ſay, till I have not a groat left to help my ſelf: Good, your Worſhip, conſider a poor Woman.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Gammer Fells, if you ſay ſo, I muſt diſcharge them; provided, they gratifie my Clerk, which is a thing common.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O, Sir, moſt willingly; there's ten ſhillings for him.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Juſtice, if they are diſcharg'd, I hope theſe are ſo too. Fare you well. Gentlemen, pray let me ſee you no more near my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: By my Sword, if I ſee you near the Houſe again, I'le kick you both upon the place I firſt meet you, though it be a thouſand Miles off. So good b'uy, honeſt Friends, good b'uy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That this blund'ring Fellow ſhould tell the Sexton our names, and the names of the Ladies, and the place from whence they came.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There was no other way in the World, to bring all out, and utterly ruine us; we are utterly undone, Ned; and I do believe 'tis impoſſible ever to bring it about again. Here comes the Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What a pox is your meaning? Alwayes playing the Fool thus, to ſend me to get a Parſon, and provide every thing, and then never come: Indeed 'tis like you; I kept my Levite in the Church from four a Clock in the Morning, till 'twas nine, that he ſwore he was almoſt ſtarv'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You have done us good Service; if you had your reward, your ears ought to be cut, for the mighty care you took in our concerns; Indeed, you ſhould have ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Indeed, Thomas, you have undergone a great deal, and done more by half then we could have deſir'd you. If the Devil himſelf had given you directions, you could not poſſibly have made us ſo miſerable.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Pray tell us ſeriouſly, what have we done to you, that ſhould provoke you to ruine us in this damnable manner? Is it your
cuſtom, pray, to betray your Friends in the drinking two Pots of Ale? Lord, Sir, how you look about you, as if you had loſt your way in a Wilderneſs. I'le warrant you don't know what you have done, now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Not he, I'le warrant, 'twas done in his ſleep; does he not uſe to walk, Franck; you have lain with him? By this light, I take him to be ſo honeſty that he would not do ſuch a thing waking. Wer't not aſleep, Tom, when thou told'ſt all?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you have been very free, both in your Examinations, and your Accuſations, and yet I have ſaid nothing; pray will you give me leave to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I; pray, what would you ſay?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why, I ſay, I'le be hang'd if this be any thing but a deſign to ſtop my mouth, and keep me from quarrelling with you, about the abuſe you put upon me, to make me ſtay in the Church ſtarving in the cold with a great greaſie Parſon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: No, no, Thomas, you are monſtrouſly miſtaken; for if that were all, you know we're well enough able to deal with you; we can ſoon knock you down with words. But pray let me ask you one thing: How many Pots of mild Beer did you and Mr. Mold drink before you came to the matter; I mean, before you made the diſcovery of my Name, and Franck Friendly's, and both the Ladies, and from whence they came?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And pray let's know why you did it, and what you got by doing of it; and whether the Devil be yet out of you, that was in you when you went about it; pray be pleas'd to ſpeak: what, are you tongue-ty'd? Don't gape, but ſpeak, Man.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Well, and what hurt did this do you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It has only ruin'd us, that's all. But why the Devil ſhould you make a confident of an old ſottiſh Fellow, that is not ſatisfy'd with cheating the living, but dead too; ſure you might have done your buſineſs without giving him a particular of our Names.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Pray, Gentlemen, how has this undone you, let me but know the meaning on't?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Why, the Sexton over-joy'd with the Money you had given him, and happy that he had news to carry to his Neighbours, went ſtrait to Mother Fells (living hard by) and being drunk with her, told her I was one of the Perſons concern'd; ſhe ſtrait gets a Warrant, and ſtayes at the Sextons, takes him and me, and both the Ladies; ſends home word to old Pett, who, whilſt we were at your Juſtices,
fetches them both away. Now, you have heard your Crime to the full, pray what have you (with a pox) to ſay for your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Tom, I don't know what ſatisfaction you can give us; unleſs you will conſent that we ſhould cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I, for Heaven's ſake do it quickly; I acknowledge I deſerve it, pray diſpatch, I hate to live one minute after I have been ſo great a Brute, to betray my Friend by folly; I was curs'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee Coxcomb, leave raving, and let's ſee what may be done to bring all about again; for being ſure of the Ladies, our caſe is not yet deſperate, they are now at their London Houſe; the Scene lyes ſomething nearer then it did.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: To make you ſome part of ſatisfaction, I'le go and kill Leftwell.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now he talks of killing Leftwell, I've a deſign in my head, may hap to do us good.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee, what is it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, Faithfull ſhall ſend Leftwell a Challenge, and in it, unleſs he meet, threaten to Piſtol him, and write to me to be his Second; and then — heark — what doſt think of this, boy?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith, Ned, I think — Pray, Sir, be quiet, we'le not have a thought of yours in the buſineſs. Ned, this would do rarely, if we could find a way to let the Ladies know on't; how muſt that be done?

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Why, I'le tell you how.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethee, good muddy brains, if thou would'ſt hold thy prating, and ſay, nor do any more than you have directions from us, things may be carried on well enough.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: If a Man commits but one fault in his life, he ſhall be ſure to hear o'nt; pray, proceed then, and let it be purely your own, and be pox'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How ſhall they know our intentions?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, I expect Runwell every minute, who will not fail to do it dextrouſly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: See where he comes.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: The poor Ladies, Sir, are utterly undone if you can find no way to relieve them; Madam Leticia is to morrow Morning to be Married to this Looby Leftwell.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Runwell, come in with me, I'le ſend a Letter to her of one deſign more, which I hope will take; Thomas, pray provide us one Parſon more preſently.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: I'le warrant you; if I don't, let me dye for't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But have a care of Carouſing again with the Sexton. Ned, you and I'le go write the Challenge, and the Letter; for the Pincipal has forgot to reade; but however, I'm ſure he can't write.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: My laſt fault makes me at preſent a little lyable to the laſh of your ugly tongue; but I'le let you alone till the buſineſs is done, and then have at you.
So god b'uy, I'le go find out my Doctor.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Pray do.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch an unhappy Accident as we have met withall, to ruine our intention: If there be a god of Love, he has very little kindneſs for us; dear Couſin, what ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: pretend thy ſelf ſick, and ſo avoid it; I proteſt, were it my caſe (as it is thine) I would rather dye, than have Leftwell, he looks ſo like a Horſe-courſer. For my part, I'm reſolv'd to have Mr. Friendly at one time or other, though he ow'd all the Ale-wives in Town Money.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Thou talk'ſt, Couſin. But prethee (if thou canſt) tell me a ſerious way.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Why then, I'le tell you; when the Parſon asks, whether you'le have him, ſay no; then I'm ſure nothing can be done: what think'ſt thou of that, Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I vow, Madam, I think you direct very well. Pray, Miſtreſs, take her advice.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: Madam, my Maſter ſends his Service, and this Letter; from Mr. Friendly this to your Ladyſhip.
Dear Miſtreſs, pity a poor Lover, that lives yet only in hopes that you will make him happy. Pray look upon me; faith, I ſhall be loſt elſe.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Good Lover, let your Maſter be ſerv'd before you. Pray, Madam, what ſayes Mr. Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Betty, I hope that this device of theirs will make us happy. Runwell, go back, and tell them wee'le obſerve their directions.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: For my part, if I fail in any thing, let me — Here's my Uncle, and the Wiſe-Acre.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What Paper was that you put into your pocket?

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Only my Taylors Bill for my laſt Gown, Sir.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Prethee, Love, let me look on't; for by that I ſhall know what you'le ſtand me in.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, forbear; when you come to pay for what I wear, you ſhall have leave to look; till then, you have no Authority, nor ſhall have over me.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I'le fetch you down in your Wedding ſhooes, i'faith, for this; to Morrow night you ſhall give me twenty kiſſes to come to Bed to you, or the Devil take me if I do it; and you are a ſawcy —

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Son, Son, you're too paſſionate; let her have her humour, for once, and keep her Paper.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Letter was left juſt now for Mr. Leftwell.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Let me ſee it.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: This is the Challenge; ſee how his colour turns, Couſin.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Indeed, he looks pale.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Oh, I'm undone, I'm undone: I would your Daughter had been drown'd ten times her depth, before I ſaw her; I'm undone, I'le have none of her; I'le not be kill'd for any Woman in England, not I; look here, do but look here; this is from one of the gang of thoſe Rogues that ran away with her this Morning: I don't like her ſo well, as to loſe my life for her; and theſe curſed Rogues will never leave till they have kill'd me; undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Leftwell, take comfort, don't ſnob ſo, and be ſatisfy'd; you are ſafe enough in the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: No, Mrs. Fickle, but I an't ſafe in the Houſe; the Rogue may bring a Cannon, that may carry quite through the Houſe for ought I know, and kill me, ſo as no body ſhall know where to find a piece of me afterwards, to tell who hurt me; would I were a thouſand Miles off. O good Ladies, ſpeak a good word for me, let me have ſome comfort from you quickly, I ſhall faint elſe.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I Proteſt, 'tis a bloody deſign. Daughter, I'le reade it to you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: O dear, Sir, if you reade, I'm a dead Man; I can't endure to hear my own Sentence; pray, put it into your Pocket, for I proteſt to you with tears, and upon my knees, that I am ready to ſwound at the ſight of it. Sweet Sir, let me ſee it no more, if you deſire I ſhould live.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Prethee Son be ſatisfy'd, I warrant I'le keep thee ſafe in the Houſe from any harm; nothing ſhall hurt you here.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I tremble as I ſtand, I proteſt, for fear I ſhould be blown up; I'le be hang'd, if he has not put Gun-powder into the Cellar.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Do you think ſo; indeed, Mr, Leftwell, it will pleaſe me mightily, to dye in ſo good Company as you are; for if the Houſe be blown up, we ſhall all go together.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p:
I don't know how it may pleaſe you, but I proteſt, I can't endure to think on't; I had rather ſee you, and a hundred more ſuch, blown up together, than be a party concern'd. O that ever I ſet my
eyes on that Woman: now muſt I dye for going about to do you a Courteſie.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, I'm ſorry you're like to ſuffer thus for me; I had rather, I aſſure you, not have you, than you ſhould be injur'd:

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: You are a couple of diſſembling Sluts; I'le warrant you'de be glad to ſee me hang'd, to have me afterwards.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, there is one Mr. Lovewell at door, very earneſt to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: O, then I'm a dead Man, hee's come to kill me. Pray good Ladies, pity a poor Man, and ſtand before me; if I ſcape killing this time, I'le never go about to Marry more.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I am aſham'd to ſee you ſuch a Coward; a Man, and cry? I'le ſend for him in, and know his bus'neſs; if I find him concern'd, I'le have him ſecur'd. Pray, Son, ſatisfie your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Secure him! that will do me a mighty kindneſs indeed, his being ſecur'd after he has kill'd me. Before he comes in, let your Servants feel in his pockets for pocket Piſtols, and Daggers, and ſeize upon his Sword.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: That's not much amiſs, it ſhall be ſo: Go tell him, if he will ſuffer that, he may come in; elſe he may ee'ne walk back again.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, I wonder what he ſhould come for; I don't care for the ſight of him, ſince he ſeduc'd me laſt away, and brought me into your diſpleaſure.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: We ſhall ſee preſently.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir; I have ſuffer'd a very ſevere ſearch; before I could obtain admittance. I muſt confeſs you have ſome reaſon to think ill of me; but now, Sir, I am ſenſible how much I had like to have injur'd you, and that deſerving Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p:
Oh, he points at me; Mercy, Mercy: dear Mr. Lovewell, let me but live one Three or Fourſcore years longer, and then you ſhall find me very willing to lay down my life at your Service. O, let
me not be cut off in my prime, before I have receiv'd half a years Rent of my Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Why, what doſt thou mean? pray be pacify'd; he has no deſign againſt you I dare ſwear.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Dear Father, ſtand before me though; for ſay what you will, I'm afraid to truſt him.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Lovewell, if you have any buſineſs, proceed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, I thought my ſelf, in point of Honour, bound to diſcover this bloody deſign laid to deſtroy your intended Son-in-Law. Look upon this Letter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, I think my ſelf much engag'd to you, if we could by your means apprehend him. My Son-in-Law has already receiv'd the Challenge; and it ſeems, he has choſe you for his Second.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, that's the thing I came about; if you will get a Warrant for him preſently, you'le find both him and me together, at the Sign of the Lamb, within two doors of Juſtice Frump's; I'le go before, and get him ready.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Now, truly, Mr. Lovewell, we both eſteem our ſelves much beholden to you, and will endeavour to make you amends.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: All I deſire, is, pardon for my laſt error. Your Servant, Sir; Ladies, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I'm glad he's gone; for he has frighted me out of the ſmall ſence I had.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Son, will you go along with me to apprehend him?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: No, Sir; I thank you for that, I'faith; I'le as ſoon thruſt my Head into a hot Oven, as venture my Noſe an Inch without the Door, for one of theſe Doggs to ſnap at.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Well, then; I'le take my Servants, and do it without you.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: My Father's gone; I wiſh they were here now.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p:
What ſhall we do with this Fool Leftwell? he'le run after my Maſter, and fetch him back again, when he ſees us going: look where he comes ſneaking, like a Prentice
Enter Leftwell. that has loſt his Maſters Money at play. Aſide. How do you, Mr. Leftwell? Are you reſolv'd to be Married to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: No, I'm reſolv'd to ſee whether I ſhall live, or dye, firſt, by your favour.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p:
Faith, Mr. Leftwell, I'm afraid, now my Uncle's gone, they
are come to kill you; theſe people knock with fury: heark, they knock again. Look out at the Window, Betty, and bring us word who 'tis, before you let 'em in.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'le run, Madam.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: O, Mrs. Fickle, if I have any heart, 'tis juſt now in my Mouth. For I feel a ſoft thing tumbling between my tongue and my teeth.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: O me, Mr. Leftwell, 'tis Mr. Friendly, and Mr. Lovewell; what will you do?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Dear Betty, put me into any place to preſerve me. O, quickly, they'le get in elſe, before I can hide my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Come along with me, I'le lock you into the Larder; come, come.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Betty, I proteſt, if thou ſav'ſt me this time, I'le have thee, and let thy Miſtreſs alone.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Hee's ſafe enough.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I've lockt up the logger-head, now I'le let them in.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Do, Betty. Couſin, put on your Scarf, and fit your ſelf for the March; delayes are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I am ready, my dear Girle; give me thy hand. I vow, I can but think, how ſimply we ſhall look, when we come to night to lye with our Lovers.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Thou art the maddeſt Wench that e're wore Petticoat: how ſhould we look, think you?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: My dear Leticia; your generous love has laid ſo many obligations on me, that nothing but the Service of an Age can ſeem a Tithe of ſatisfaction. Which to be paid —

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, forbear your Complements at preſent, and let's make haſte to carry on the work we come about.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Bravely propos'd, my pretty Miſtreſs; if they lye lingring longer, wee'le away, and laugh at them. What doſt thou mean, Ned? to be (at this haſty time) telling thy Miſtreſs, in blanck verſe, that which ſhe has been ſatisfy'd in theſe ſix Moneths; how much you love her, and how much ſhe's more than you deſerve; why, ſhe knows both the one, and the other.

sp.speaker: Let.
sp.p: Sir, their advice at this time is not much amiſs; therefore let's make haſte.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Betty, is the Coaſt clear?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There's none but the Old Chare-Woman in the Houſe; and ſhe's aſleep in the Chimney Corner.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: I believe Mr. Leftwell will make a foul Larder; ſhall we leave him under lock and key?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Hang him, I'le leave the Key in the door, that the next that comes may let him out.

div.head: Scena quarta.
div.stage: Enter Pett, and Moſes, with Servants, at Juſtice Frump's Houſe; Frump, and Stingey.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mr. Juſtice, 'tis intollerable; a Man muſt ſtand an hour, or two, hearing you talk Non-ſence, inſtead of Law, to delay the time, when a Perſon comes to you in haſte, upon ſo great an occaſion as this is, a matter of life and death.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Stingey, make him a Warrant; but, Sir, a Warrant that is made upon life and death by a Juſtice of Peace cannot be had for leſs than a Crown; if you will be at the price of it, my Man will make it you. Sir, 'tis nothing to me, the Money comes into his Pocket; I proteſt, I don't deſire a farthing of you, not I.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Sir, I don't value a Crown, as worth a thought; but I have been a Juſtice my ſelf, and never heard of ſuch a thing as this.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: I grant you, Sir, not by a Juſtice of London, but alwayes by a Juſtice of Peace of Middleſen. My Man, Sir, knows the Law, as well as moſt do; and he ſhall ſwear it, if you deſire to hear him.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: He won't, ſure. I'le give him ten ſhillings for the Warrant, if he will.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, give me the Book.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, here's a Crown for your Warrant; I would not for a World be ſo inſtrumental in thy deſtruction. God b'ye, Sir; I believe you have kept me ſo long, I have loſt my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Pay me for my part, Stingey; I ought to have ſix pence more than you; for indeed, there is no ſuch price upon any Warrant.

sp.speaker: Sting.
sp.p:
That I know, therefore I offer'd to ſwear it, whereas you
only told him ſo; that the Gentleman might be ſatisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Frump.
sp.p: Give me half a Crown then; and take your Hat, and fetch a quart of Ale for your Miſtreſs out of your Money.

div.head: Scena Ultima.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What, hoe! Daughter, Niece, Betty! where are theſe Girles? What, would they offer to go out, and leave the Houſe empty? Go ſome of you, and ſee if you can find them. This idle Juſtice keeping me ſo long, has made me miſs him; but I ſuppoſe, Mr. Lovewell will at Night inform me where I may have them. What, have you found them?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: No, Sir; nor any body, but the old Woman aſleep in the Kitchin Chimney.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What ſhould become of them, and Mr. Leftwell? There can be no trick put upon me, forſure they're all together.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: within. I'm here, Sir; is the Houſe clear? Is there no danger?

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Prethee, where art, Man?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I am here in ſome place, I don't know what you call it; but 'tis where the cold Meat, and the Kitchin-ſtuff ſtands.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What, are you lockt in the Larder?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: I, Sir, the Larder; Betty lockt me in two hours ago; I thank her, ſhe ſav'd my life by't; but now I hope you'le let me out

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Moſes, unlock the door.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: O, Father, we have been in ſuch a fright ſince you went; you were no ſooner gone, but comes Ned Lovewell, and Franck Friendly, with a full Reſolution to kill me, but Betty ſav'd my life. I heard them carry away your Couſin and your Daughter; whom, I believe verily they'le kill for my ſake; and that will be a ſad thing: but better them, than I.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: This was a trick, a deſign; I find it now too late.

div.stage: Enter to them, Lovewell, Leticia, Friendly, Fickle, Runwell, and Betty.
div.p: Sir, I was ſending after you; 'tis well you have brought my Family home again.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: With all Humility we beg your Bleſſing, as your Son and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Ned Lovewell, I'faith, I'm glad thou haſt got her; now you will let me live at quiet, I hope, and I'le forgive you all the Money I lent you. I'le ee'ne ſtrike in with Betty.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: What, have you got my Daughter there? If you have an Eſtate to keep her, 'tis well; you ſhall have none of me: therefore get you out of my ſight.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir, your Sentence is very ſevere; will you pleaſe but to hear me.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have heard and ſeen too much of you already; but there's your way out, and you may take your Lady with you, for ſhe ſhall ne're come here again.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Lovewell, before you go, will you hear me; my Uncle can't hinder me of my Fortune, part of which is at your Service.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: No, Goſſip, it ſhall ne're be ſaid, that my Daughter was beholden to you for her maintenance. Mr. Lovewell, I know you're a Gentleman, and I find you're Ingenious; but as you have no Eſtate, if I could have hinder'd it, you ſhould not have Marry'd her; but I will be ſatisfi'd, ſince I ſee 'tis decreed: I am imform'd too, you have behav'd your ſelf handſomly, and honeſtly, and in that believe my Daughter not quite caſt away. My Bleſſing be upon you both; and I'm apt to believe you'le uſe her well, which I doubt whether Leftwell would have done. Couſin, I wiſh you joy; your Portion ſhall be paid you when you pleaſe; and if you learn to be thrifty, you may be happy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: May Heaven, Sir, reward your kindneſs with continual joy; and may I live no longer than that day when I forget to pay you moſt obedient Service.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Sir, I hope in a little time to let you ſee the Fruits of our labour, and am reſolv'd to make you a great Uncle, as ſoon as my Friend Lovewell ſhall a Grand-ſire.

sp.speaker: Fick.
sp.p: O, Sir, theſe liberal promiſers are alwayes ſhort pay-maſters.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: How do you intend to diſpoſe of your ſelf Mr. Leftwell, after your great fright?

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Why, I deſire you'de give me leave to Marry your Maid; a Man may have her without danger of being Murder'd, and I have alwayes had a mind to her.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: Betty, come hither, give me your hand, I'le make the Match; it ſhall be done to Morrow Morning.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Now my Miſtreſs is provided for, I begin to love my ſelf ſo well, that I cannot find in my heart to refuſe a good Fortune, though it come by a Fool; whom I believe I can baſte into ſubmiſſion.

div.p: Sir, it ſhall be as you command.

sp.speaker: Run.
sp.p: I'm not a whit ſorry I ha' loſt my Miſtreſs, ſince I ſee ſhe's better provided; neither will I deſpair of making my Fortune by her favour, out of this Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and Ladies, your Servant; hearing that all things and parties are agreed, I've brought ſome Friends of mine that reſolve to give you a Song and a Dance.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Honeſt Tom, 'tis kindly done; and they will, I believe, be very acceptable to all the good Company; but wee'le Dance our ſelves, if your Friends, as you call them, will but ſtrike up. I wiſh thou hadſt a Miſtreſs too, to make thy happineſs equal ours.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: Mine wants but little on't; for I'm reſolv'd to live as well as you: now you two are rich, I'le ne're be poor.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou art ours for ever, Tom.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But he ſhould keep his Hands clean, then.

sp.speaker: Faith.
sp.p: What, won't Marriage tame you? Still abuſive? I muſt ſtop your Mouths with Muſick.

sp.speaker: Pett.
sp.p: All excellent good, i'faith; very good indeed: pray, Son, and Nephew, walk in, and leade your Wives to Supper, for it grows near that time; for Betty's ſake, you ſhall be welcome too, Mr. Leftwell.

sp.speaker: Left.
sp.p: Nay, I care not for whoſe ſake it is; ſo I have but enough, I ſhall be very well ſatisfy'd. Come, Sweeting.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If we had been unhappy in the loſs of our Miſtreſſes now, I ſhould have grown almoſt out of love with Honeſty.

lg.l: O, there's nothing like it.
Let all that would do ill be rul'd by me;
For by this Preſident you plainly ſee
Fate ſtill reſerves rewards for Honeſty.
NOw, Gallants, your reſult; we fain would know
Whether you Judge it fit to live, or no:
This truth wee'le ſay, to mitigate its Crime,
It is his firſt; made in a fortnight's time.
A Critick, for that Reaſon, ought to give,
If not a Pardon, ſurely, a Reprieve.
'Twould be high Tyranny for to inveigh,
In cruel terms, againſt an Infant Play.
But if your Laws all mercy do deny;
Hee's ſure to have relief in equity:
He appeals thither, as his proper Sphear,
Nor can he be compelled to appear
In any other Court; but could he by perſwaſions draw
You to be kind in equity and Law;
And ſee it ſign'd with all your hands, hee'le be,
Though now but weak, your's in Maturity.
